华盛顿（美联社）——美巡赛周三表示，它将在下个月出席参议院小组委员会的听证会，该小组委员会的领导人要求美巡赛、沙特高尔夫利益集团和 LIV Golf 的高管在国会调查颠覆这项运动的商业交易时作证。

康涅狄格州民主党参议员理查德·布卢门撒尔宣布，参议院常设调查小组委员会将于 7 月 11 日举行听证会，审查涉及美巡赛、沙特阿拉伯主权财富基金和欧洲巡回赛的协议，以汇集商业业务和权利一家新公司。

布卢门撒尔在一份声明中表示：“我们的目标是揭露美巡赛与沙特公共投资基金的交易的真相，以及沙特的收购对这个受人尊敬的美国机构的未来和我们的国家利益意味着什么。” “美国人应该知道这个新实体的结构和治理方式。协议中的主要参与者最有能力提供这些信息，他们欠国会和美国人民在公共场合给出答案。”

布卢门撒尔邀请PGA巡回赛专员杰伊·莫纳汉、公共投资基金总裁亚西尔·鲁迈扬和LIV首席执行官格雷格·诺曼作证。

莫纳汉于 6 月 9 日致函各立法者，三天前美巡赛令人震惊地宣布达成一项协议，该协议将结束美巡赛与公共投资基金之间的所有诉讼。他在信中表示，由于美国与沙特的地缘政治联盟，巡回赛“由我们自己决定”，以阻止沙特阿拉伯通过 LIV Golf 接管这项运动。

去年，LIV Golf 以 1 亿美元或更多的签约奖金吸引了一些高尔夫巨星，促使 PGA 巡回赛做出回应，向自己的锦标赛钱包投入了数百万美元。

美巡赛在一份声明中表示：“我们期待着出席参议院小组委员会，回答他们关于框架协议的问题，我们相信，这将使美巡赛保持职业高尔夫未来领导者的地位，并使我们的球员、球迷和我们的运动受益。” “该框架的第一阶段已经结束了与 LIV Golf 的昂贵诉讼。

“当我们进入下一阶段时，我们期待继续昨晚与球员进行的富有成效的对话，听取他们的反馈，并努力谈判达成一项符合他们最大利益的最终协议，并确保巡回赛能够引领任何新的冒险”。

美巡赛在6月6日的公告中表示，Al-Rumayyan将担任新公司的董事长，莫纳汉将担任首席执行官。两名美巡赛董事会成员艾德·赫利希 (Ed Herlihy) 和吉米·邓恩 (Jimmy Dunne)将加入他们的执行委员会。

此后，莫纳汉因“健康状况”退出了巡回赛。他的两名高管负责巡回赛的日常运营。阿尔-鲁迈扬表示，诺曼直到交易达成前不久才得知这笔交易。宣布。

自去年夏天以来，司法部反垄断部门一直在审查高尔夫行业的情况，现在它也开始审查巡回赛与沙特的协议以及它是否违反联邦反垄断法。调查尚处于早期阶段。

辛辛那提（美联社）——杰克·弗雷利（Jake Fraley）在第八局打出两分全垒打，打破了平局，辛辛那提红人队将他们的大满贯最佳连胜纪录扩大到了 11 场，周三以 5-3 击败科罗拉多洛矶队，取得三连胜。扫。

新秀埃利·德拉·克鲁兹 (Elly De La Cruz) 向左击出一记一垒安打，在对阵丹尼尔·巴德 (Daniel Bard) 的比赛中打出二垒安打 (3-1)，弗雷利 (Fraley) 在右侧击出一球越过人墙，帮助红军实现大联盟最佳第 12 次翻盘落基山脉队取得了本赛季的胜利，而落基山脉队则遭遇了赛季最糟糕的八连败。四局后辛辛那提队以 3-0 落后。

国联中部领先的红军（40胜35负）已经连续横扫了三场系列赛，并连续五个系列赛获胜。他们的连胜是俱乐部自1957年12连胜以来最长的连胜。

当布伦顿·多伊尔（Brenton Doyle）以全垒打领先时，安德鲁·阿博特（Andrew Abbott）取得了他职业生涯的第一分。但这位新秀左手投手从那时起就表现稳定，在六局中三振了职业生涯最高的 10 分，并丢了 3 分，全部都是单打本垒打。阿博特在第六局三振出局。

阿伯特与卢卡斯·西姆斯、伊恩·吉鲍特和巴克·法默联手，在第四节后让落基队一分未得。吉鲍特（8-1）在第八局中围绕着第一支单打投球，而法默则在第九局中完成了五次尝试中的第二次扑救。落基山脉队有 15 次三振。

光芒 7、金莺 2

英石。佛罗里达州圣彼得堡（美联社）——新秀泰姬·布拉德利在六局中失一分，创下职业生涯新高，兰迪·阿罗扎雷纳和艾萨克·帕雷德斯击出本垒打，坦帕湾队击败巴尔的摩队，在美联东区排名前两名的球队之间平分两场系列赛。

布拉德利 (5-3) 放弃了 3 个安打并三振了 8 个。

阿罗扎雷纳和帕雷德斯以连续全垒打开始了四分第二局，对阵泰勒·威尔斯（6-3），泰勒·威尔斯在局中也出现了两次失误。

阿罗扎雷纳在两连胜第七场打出一打点，帮助坦帕湾队主场将战绩提高到 32 胜 8 负，并阻止了整个赛季三场比赛的下滑。

拉蒙·乌里亚斯和冈纳尔·亨德森为金莺队击出全垒打，金莺队落后第一名光芒队五分。

太空人 10、大都会 8

休斯顿（美联社）——亚历克斯·布雷格曼打出三支安打，雅纳·迪亚兹和查斯·麦考密克都击出两分全垒打，帮助休斯顿队击败纽约队赢得三场系列赛。

由于克里斯蒂安·哈维尔 (Cristian Javier) 的开局不佳，休斯顿队早早以 4-2 落后。麦考密克在第三局打出四分全垒打，使太空人队取得领先。大都会队在第四节上半打平，但太空人队在局末拿下三分，迪亚兹的全垒打突显了太空人队的领先优势。

丹尼尔·沃格尔巴赫 (Daniel Vogelbach) 打出赛季最高的三支安打并打出 3 个打点，皮特·阿隆索 (Pete Alonso) 打出他的第 23 个本垒打，大都会队在以 11-1 赢得系列赛揭幕战后连续第二场失利。

毛里西奥·杜邦（Mauricio Dubón）在第四节以一出局的情况下打出双垒安打，布雷格曼（Bregman）打出一垒安打得分，使太空人队以7-6领先。迪亚兹将多米尼克·莱昂内 (2-2) 的下一个投球送到左中锋，打出他五场比赛中的第三个本垒打，将比分追至 9-6。

哈维尔在指挥方面表现不佳，仅在 2 1/3 局内就被安打 4 次，失分 4 次，并有职业生涯最高的 5 次保送。菲尔·马顿 (Phil Maton) (1-2) 在 1 1/3 局无分局中三振三振获胜，瑞安·普莱斯利 (Ryan Pressly) 投出了完美的第九球，完成了他的第 14 次扑救。

国民队 3 场，红雀队 0 场

华盛顿（美联社）——特雷弗·威廉姆斯（Trevor Williams）在持续下雨的情况下击败了迈尔斯·米科拉斯（Miles Mikolas），CJ·艾布拉姆斯（CJ Abrams）打出三投三中的本垒打，华盛顿击败圣路易斯结束了五场比赛的下滑。

第五局雨势越来越大，艾布拉姆斯将米科拉斯（4-5）的一记快球送入客队左中的牛棚，比分1-0。杰默·坎德拉里奥(Jeimer Candelario)在第六局中打出两垒安打，在第八局中打出一记滚地球，为华盛顿队打进了跑动。

威廉姆斯（4胜4负）今年首次进入第七局，失5支安打，投出75个球，让红雀队冷静下来，红雀队已经取得了四连胜。圣路易斯队本赛季第七次被排除在外。

亨特·哈维投出第九球，这是他的第四次扑救。

小熊 8、海盗 3

匹兹堡（美联社）——凯尔·亨德里克斯（Kyle Hendricks）在第七局有效投球，尼科·霍尔纳（Nico Hoerner）击出全垒打，三垒安打并打出三分，芝加哥队击败匹兹堡队完成三场横扫。

亨德里克斯（3胜2负）为小熊队赢得了连续第三场先发，小熊队已经赢得了九场比赛中的八场，这为他们在周六开始的在英国伦敦对阵对手圣路易斯的周末系列赛中提供了强大的动力。

霍尔纳在第三局击出里奇希尔 (6-7) 的两分三垒安打，并在第七局打出单人本垒打。伊恩·哈普 (Ian Happ) 两次翻倍，并获得两分。

海盗队已经遭遇九连败，这是自 2021 年 6 月 6 日至 16 日连续九场比赛下滑以来最长的连败。当时球队正处于全面重建模式。匹兹堡相信他们正越来越接近成为一个竞争者，但在过去的两周里，19胜9负的开局所带来的良好氛围已经消退。海盗队在过去 45 场比赛中战绩为 15 胜 30 负。

老虎队 9、皇家队 4

底特律（美联社）——扎克·肖特打出全垒打并打出三分，哈维尔·贝兹打出他的第 1,000 支安打，底特律击败了低迷的堪萨斯城。

皇家队在 18 场比赛中输掉了 15 场。

马修·博伊德（5胜5负）为底特律队在六局比赛中失两分和六支安打。他没有上垒就三振七次。

布雷迪·辛格（4-7）连续第三次输掉比赛，在七局中丢掉五分、七支安打和上垒。

贝兹在第三局中帮助老虎队以 4-2 领先，凯里·卡彭特 (Kerry Carpenter) 击出他的第 1,000 支安打。

蓝鸟队 6、马林鱼队 3

迈阿密（美联社）——马特·查普曼击出全垒打并打出双垒安打，凯文·高斯曼投出六局多三分球，多伦多队击败了迈阿密队。

卡万·比吉奥 (Cavan Biggio) 接替博·比切特 (Bo Bichette) 替补，为蓝鸟队打出双打和单打。比切特以 101 次安打领先美国联盟，并参加了多伦多队的前 75 场比赛，但由于左手拇指不适而缺席。

路易斯·阿拉埃斯 (Luis Arraez) 代表马林鱼队 5 投 2 中，命中率为大联盟领先的 0.398。

高斯曼（7胜3负）在六局或更多局的第12场比赛中被安打八次并三振六次。乔丹·罗马诺完成了他的第 22 次扑救。

马林鱼队先发球员桑迪·阿尔坎塔拉（Sandy Alcantara）又遭遇了一场艰难的比赛。这位国联赛扬奖卫冕者在七局比赛中丢掉了 5 分和 10 个安打，自责分率升至 5.08。阿尔坎塔拉（2胜6负）在过去的两场首发中均取得了两位数的安打数。

响尾蛇 5, 酿酒人 1

密尔沃基（美联社）——扎克·加伦投了七局，取得了第九场胜利，亚利桑那州击败了密尔沃基。

亚利桑那队在系列赛中从酿酒人队手中拿下了三分中的两分。

圣加仑 (9-2) 将酿酒人队限制为一分三安打。他保送一球，三振四球。他在第五局中让雷梅尔·塔皮亚（Raimel Tapia）打出单人本垒打。

斯科特·麦高夫投了两局没有得分，四次三振，结束了胜利并完成了他的第四次扑救。

国联西区领先的响尾蛇队在第六局对阵酿酒人队的中继投手埃尔维斯·佩格罗 (Elvis Peguero) 时取得突破 (1-1)。帕文·史密斯（Pavin Smith）一出局，中外野手乔伊·维默（Joey Wiemer）未能干净利落地接住伊曼纽尔·里维拉（Emmanuel Rivera）的中场单打，将比分追平。里维拉 (Rivera) 接阿莱克·托马斯 (Alek Thomas) 右线直线单打得分，亚利桑那队 2-1 领先。

华盛顿（美联社）——周三公布的法庭文件显示，亨特·拜登将于下个月见法官，与检察官就税收和枪支指控正式达成认罪协议，这可能会让总统乔·拜登的儿子免于入狱。

美国地区法官玛丽莲·诺雷卡 (Maryellen Noreika) 仍必须批准经过漫长的联邦调查后达成的认罪协议。它要求总统的儿子承认两项未缴税的轻罪。亨特·拜登还必须遵守法庭规定的条件，以免他因枪支重罪指控而受到全面起诉。

听证会定于 7 月 26 日举行，包括初次出庭和认罪协议。

周二认罪协议的消息引发了共和党人的批评，他们正在对亨特·拜登商业交易的几乎所有方面进行国会调查，包括对外付款。

周三在斯德哥尔摩旅行的总检察长梅里克·加兰表示，特拉华州美国检察官戴维·韦斯“拥有完全权力，可以在他认为适当的情况下决定此事”。这就是他所做的。”

在特朗普面临历史性刑事起诉之际，前总统唐纳德·特朗普和其他共和党人指出此案引发了对司法部独立性的质疑。对特朗普的指控是由一名特别检察官提出的，目的是避免给人留下政治冲突的印象。

与此同时，对亨特·拜登的指控是由美国检察官韦斯提出的，韦斯由特朗普任命，并在拜登政府期间继续调查，某些方面仍在继续。诺雷卡也于 2017 年被特朗普任命。

亨特·拜登的律师表示，认罪是为了对他“在人生的动荡和毒瘾时期”所犯的错误承担责任，他的理解是，这结束了对他的委托人长达五年的调查。

丹佛（美联社）——周三，17 名前美国职业棒球大联盟球探起诉该联盟、其球队和专员罗布·曼弗雷德（Rob Manfred），称自己因年龄而受到歧视。

该诉讼已向丹佛美国地方法院提起。前童子军指控违反 1967 年联邦就业年龄歧视法以及 11 个州和纽约市的法律。

球探人数从 55 人到 71 人不等，他们声称自己在 2020-22 赛季期间受到了歧视。他们表示，美国职业棒球大联盟和各球队“已采取行动阻止重新雇用年长的球探或拒绝重新雇用年长的球探”。

他们还表示，美国职业棒球大联盟（MLB）的一项规定，当球探与新球队签约时，他们的工资会被抵消，但他们仍由被解雇的前球队支付工资，这是歧视性的。

美国职业棒球大联盟在一份声明中表示，“期待在法庭上反驳这些指控”，但不会对未决诉讼发表评论。

这些前球探还声称，MLB 在 2015 年终止了符合就业资格的球探名单，在 2018 年终止 MLB 球探局的决定具有歧视性，并且 MLB 以分析和冠状病毒大流行为借口来淘汰老球探。

Kilgore & Kilgore 律师米切尔·C·阿贝塔 (Mitchell C. Abeita) 在一份声明中表示：“这起诉讼涉及一项体育运动中的年龄歧视，这项运动本应重视历史、传统，并在赛场上提供最好的产品。”

弗吉尼亚州里士满（美联社）——在本周的弗吉尼亚州初选中，被罢黜的州议员数量创下历史新高，此次初选将举行大约四打立法竞选，为这场艰苦的大选确定各党派的候选人名单。

众议院和州参议院的每个席位都将在 11 月的选举周期中进行投票，这将有助于确定共和党州长格伦·扬金 (Glenn Youngkin)在其任期的最后两年中能够实现多少立法议程。

弗吉尼亚州目前在政治上存在分歧，其不同寻常的非年度立法选举通常会引起全国的广泛关注，作为进入明年中期或总统周期的选民情绪的可能晴雨表。

以下是周二结果和未来展望的一些关键要点：

历史性的营业额

早在周二晚上之前，很明显，在两党重新划分选区的进程的推动下，大会将出现大规模更替，这一进程颠覆了该州的政治版图，导致了一系列退休人员的涌入，并削弱了现任者典型的知名度优势。周二少数公职人员的失败只会增加这一人员流动。

例如，在 40 名成员的参议院中，至少有 15 名是新成员。

根据无党派弗吉尼亚公共访问项目的分析，周二被罢黜的州参议员人数（五人）相当于自 1999 年以来在初选中失利的所有参议员人数。

共和党做出更多中间派选择

在全州范围内，参加共和党竞选的选民——包括少数几个战场选区——以中右翼或务实的方式提名候选人，而不是局外人、煽动者和/或极右强硬派。

德尔·塔拉·杜兰特 (Del. Tara Durant) 击败了餐馆老板马特·斯特里克兰 (Matt Strickland)，马特·斯特里克兰 (Matt Strickland) 在竞争竞争激烈、倾向红色的弗雷德里克斯堡地区参议院席位的提名时援引了“粉碎当权派”的口号。德尔·艾米丽·布鲁尔 (Del. Emily Brewer) 击败了前 NASCAR 车手赫米·萨德勒 (Hermie Sadler)，后者批评了后者她被认为过于温和，无法获得另一个竞争性参议院席位的提名。

几位最强烈支持前总统唐纳德·特朗普关于 2020 年选举中普遍存在舞弊的虚假说法的候选人被赶下台，其中包括参议员阿曼达·蔡斯，她称自己为“穿高跟鞋的特朗普”。她没有承认，并于周三表示，她是“寻求法律顾问”对结果提出质疑。另一位戴夫·拉洛克 (Del. Dave LaRock) 被认为是谢南多厄河谷公开八路参议院席位的最佳竞争者，但他和其他人被农民蒂米·弗伦奇 (Timmy French) 击败他在竞选活动中重点关注农业和商业问题以及对教育和执法的支持。

此前通过政党运作程序确定的提名也出现了类似的动态。

前长期共和党策略师塔克·马丁表示，结果表明选民优先考虑“选举性而不是娱乐价值”。他表达了人们普遍持有的观点，即共和党要想在大选中重新夺回参议院席位还有很长的路要走，但他表示，该党在当晚以“尽可能最好的姿态”走出了困境。

民主党选民罢免了几位温和派人士

民主党在本周期面临更多的初选，最终导致了更多的人事变动，包括罢免了参议院几位较为温和的议员。

现任议员乔·莫里西 (Joe Morrissey)、乔治·巴克 (George Barker)、莱昂内尔·斯普鲁尔 (Lionell Spruill) 和查普·彼得森 (Chap Petersen) 均被击败，而第五位候选人杰里米·麦克派克 (Jeremy McPike) 的竞选则势均力敌。彼得森的失败被认为是最大的冷门——他的花费以近 6 比 1 的优势超过了挑战者萨达姆·萨利姆。

观察人士表示，如果这些竞选中的初选获胜者继续在大选中获胜，他们将在大选中受到极大青睐，这将推动民主党参议院核心小组向左倾斜。但摇摆选区并没有出现任何损失，那里得到党团领导支持的候选人在两场关键的战场竞选中获胜。

参议员斯科特·苏罗维尔 (Scott Surovell) 表示：“虽然我们会怀念一些与我们共事多年的议员，但我们处于有利地位，可以赢得必要的竞选，以保护和扩大我们在参议院的多数席位。”与记者通话。

共和党人试图将这一结果视为该党正在努力走向边缘的标志。

“那些把弗吉尼亚放在第一位的理性民主党人已经不复存在了。他们已被新的提名人取代，新的提名人将在该国最自由的立法机构中找到志同道合的同志，”扬金的政治行动委员会在周三的一份备忘录中表示。

但这一趋势也有明显的例外：在弗吉尼亚州北部，苏哈斯·苏布拉马尼亚姆轻松击败了前德尔·易卜拉欣·萨米拉，萨米拉批评他领导了一个包括共和党在内的核心小组，旨在加强两党合作。在夏洛茨维尔的一个席位上，长期现任参议员克雷·迪兹（Creigh Deeds）击败了进步挑战者莎莉·哈德森（Sally Hudson）。克雷·迪兹是一位温和派，近年来在枪支问题上转向左倾。

立法者还指出，一些可能的新成员将增加大会的多样性，这种多样性在最近的选举周期中有所增加。

堕胎权成为焦点

堕胎权利倡导者表示，拉什雷切·艾尔德击败民主党人莫里西，这是自罗伊诉韦德案失败以来该问题如何激励选民的另一个选举例子。莫里西此前曾发起一项限制堕胎的法案。

艾尔德将莫里西在这个问题上的立场——而不是他长期以来的个人争议——集中在她的竞选活动中，并彻底击败了他。

莫里西支持在怀孕早期进行堕胎，他被视为可能对扬金提议的 15 周堕胎禁令进行摇摆投票。他的失败以及艾尔德现在在民主党占多数的弗吉尼亚州中部第 13 选区取得胜利的明确道路意味着杨金的计划将更加艰难。

弗吉尼亚州计划生育倡导者组织执行董事杰米·洛克哈特 (Jamie Lockhart) 在一份声明中表示：“这对于 SD-13 居民、弗吉尼亚人以及我们整个东南地区的医疗保健服务来说都是一场胜利。”

大选的快速转向

两党领导人迅速将注意力转向大选之战，并预览了各自的信息，双方都将对方描绘成极端主义者。

民主党众议院领袖唐·斯科特表示，他的政党将反击共和党人“攻击投票权、禁书、攻击教室里的儿童”以及想要实施企业减税的州长。

众议院议长托德·吉尔伯特表示，民主党“拒绝追究暴力犯罪分子的责任，希望提高税收，并且家长不参与孩子的教育。”

希夫成为第25位受到谴责的众议院议员。他在投票前表现得目中无人，称他将把正式的反对视为“荣誉徽章”，并指责他的共和党同事听从前总统的吩咐。

投票结束后，当希夫到会议厅前接受正式谴责时，通常庄严的仪式变得更加庆祝。数十名民主党人挤在前面，为希夫鼓掌欢呼，拍拍他的背。他们高呼“不！”、“耻辱！”和“亚当！亚当！”

当众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡（Kevin McCarthy）按照谴责后的传统开始大声宣读该决议时，民主党人质问他，直到他停下来并放弃，离开了众议院。

“谴责我们所有人，”一名民主党人喊道。

众议院情报委员会前民主党主席、特朗普首次弹劾审判的首席检察官希夫长期以来一直是共和党的头号政治目标。今年夺回多数席位后不久，共和党就阻止他进入情报小组。

上周，超过 20 名共和党人与民主党一起投票阻止了这项谴责决议，但在该措施的发起人、佛罗里达州共和党众议员安娜·宝琳娜·卢纳 (Anna Paulina Luna) 取消了一项条款后，他们本周改变了投票方式，该条款如果众议院道德准则通过，可能会对希夫处以 1600 万美元的罚款。委员会认定他撒谎了。上周投票反对该决议的几名共和党人表示，他们反对以这种方式对国会议员处以罚款。

周三的最终投票结果是 213 票对 209 票，按照党派划分，少数成员出席了投票。

修改后的决议称，希夫在特朗普担任总统期间担任权力职务，并“滥用这种信任，称有证据表明特朗普竞选团队与俄罗斯勾结”。希夫是这位前总统最直言不讳的批评者之一，因为司法部和共和党领导的众议院都于 2017 年对特朗普与俄罗斯的关系展开了调查。两项调查的结论是俄罗斯干预了 2016 年总统选举，但都没有发现俄罗斯干预美国总统选举的证据。犯罪阴谋。

决议称：“希夫代表故意欺骗他的委员会、国会和美国人民。”

在过去 20 年里，众议院只谴责过另外两名议员。亚利桑那州共和党众议员保罗·戈萨尔 (Paul Gosar) 于 2021 年因在推特上发布一段动画视频而受到谴责，视频中他用剑袭击了纽约州众议员亚历山大·奥卡西奥-科尔特斯 (Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez)。纽约前民主党众议员查理·兰格尔 (Charlie Rangel) 于 2010 年因严重的财务和竞选不当行为而受到谴责。

这种谴责本身没有任何实际效果，只是提供了一个标志着立法者职业生涯的历史性脚注。但共和党决议还将对希夫的行为展开道德调查。

尽管希夫并未发起 2017 年国会对特朗普与俄罗斯关系的调查——当时的众议院情报委员会主席、后来成为特朗普最热心捍卫者之一的共和党人德文·努涅斯 (Devin Nunes) 发起了这项调查——但支持他谴责的共和党人周三指责他的行为他们说这是该调查以及特朗普自己的司法部同年启动的单独调查的后果。

卢纳表示，希夫关于有证据反对特朗普的言论“撕裂了全国各地的美国家庭”，并且他“永久破坏了家庭关系”。一些人指责他为领导司法部调查的时任特别检察官罗伯特·穆勒 (Robert Mueller) 花费了超过 3000 万美元。

希夫表示，谴责决议“将指责我无所不能，是某些巨大的深州阴谋的领导者，当然，这是无稽之谈。”

民主党人积极地为他们的同事辩护。领导特朗普第二次弹劾的马里兰州众议员杰米·拉斯金 (Jamie Raskin) 称这次弹劾行动是“代表唐纳德·特朗普的令人尴尬的报复之旅”。

领导司法部为期两年的调查的穆勒确定，俄罗斯代表竞选团队进行了干预，特朗普的竞选团队欢迎这种帮助。但穆勒的团队没有发现竞选活动串谋影响选举，司法部也没有建议提出任何刑事指控。

努涅斯发起的众议院情报委员会调查同样发现俄罗斯干预了选举，但没有证据表明存在犯罪阴谋。希夫是当时该小组中民主党的最高领导人。

希夫上周表示，谴责决议是麦卡锡在政府支出争论中向他的会议提出的“红肉”。希夫说，共和党人正试图表达对特朗普的忠诚。

他说，他在三年前的弹劾程序中警告全国，特朗普“会继续做得更糟。当然，他的表现更糟糕，对国会大厦进行了暴力袭击。”

2018年民主党赢得众议院多数席位后，特朗普威胁要停止对乌克兰的军事援助，并敦促该国总统调查当时的候选人乔·拜登，众议院以滥用权力为由弹劾他。希夫是向参议院提出定罪案的首席众议院检察官，他反复辩称“正确很重要”。共和党领导的众议院最终宣告他无罪。

特朗普在卸任一年后，因其在 2021 年 1 月 6 日国会大厦叛乱中所扮演的角色而再次遭到弹劾。参议院再次宣告特朗普无罪。

在针对希夫的谴责决议中，卢纳还引用了特别检察官约翰·达勒姆5月份发布的一份报告，该报告发现联邦调查局仓促对特朗普的竞选活动进行调查，并且过于依赖原始和未经证实的情报。

达勒姆表示，调查人员在推进调查时一再依赖“确认偏见”，忽视或合理化那些削弱特朗普与俄罗斯阴谋前提的证据。但他并未声称政治偏见或党派偏见是联邦调查局行动的指导因素。

特朗普声称，达勒姆的报告将揭露“世纪罪行”，并揭露政府高级官员旨在破坏他的候选资格和后来的总统任期的“深层国家阴谋”。但调查只得出了一项定罪——一名鲜为人知的联邦调查局雇员的认罪——而另外两起案件均在审判中以无罪释放告终。

周三，就在投票前，希夫的竞选团队发出了一封筹款电子邮件，称卢纳提出了“另一项谴责我的决议”。

电子邮件中写道：“投票和辩论即将进行”，并要求收件人捐款以帮助他反击。 “再一次，我必须在众议院聆听MAGA共和党人对我散布虚假和诽谤性的谎言。”

民主党人还认为，众议院的谴责决议是为了转移人们对特朗普最近对联邦指控囤积机密文件（其中一些涉及敏感的国家安全问题）并试图隐瞒这些机密文件的指控的注意力。大多数忠于特朗普的众议院共和党人表示，起诉书进一步证明政府正在密谋反对这位前总统。

“这不是一项严肃的决议，”宾夕法尼亚州民主党众议员马德琳·迪恩说，而是一场政治表演，目的是“转移人们对唐纳德·特朗普的违法历史和现在的起诉的注意力”。

Here's what it is and how it's made

美国政府允许销售由动物细胞制成的鸡肉。

周三，加州公司 Upside Foods 和 Good Meat 获得农业部销售其产品的许可。

不需要饲养和宰杀牲畜来生产这种新型肉类，支持者认为这对动物和环境都更好，因为不需要清理土地来放牧或种植饲料。

目前，美国有超过 10 亿英亩的土地用于农业，占总土地的一半以上，其中大部分用于放牧。

它是什么？

它是从钢罐中的动物细胞中培育出来的肉。虽然它在业内被称为培育肉，但有时也被称为培养肉、实验室培育肉或细胞肉。全球有超过 150 家公司正在尝试开发这些食品。他们正在研究各种肉类：鸡肉、牛肉、猪肉和羊肉。

从哪里可以获得？

目前，你无法在杂货店购买这些新肉类——它们最初将在餐馆推出。 CRB 细胞食品项目经理塞巴斯蒂安·博恩 (Sebastian Bohn) 表示，预计未来两到五年内，培育肉将在越来越多的餐馆和小型零售商处销售，七到十年内将出现在超市货架上。一家密苏里州公司，为制药、生物技术和食品公司设计和建造设施。

它是如何制成的？

它从细胞开始，细胞可以来自受精卵，这是最初取自活体动物的特殊储存细胞或组织库。将细胞与细胞生长和分裂所需的营养物肉汤混合。细胞被触发转变为骨骼肌、脂肪和结缔组织。几天或几周后，细胞从罐中取出并成型为产品，例如块状。

用这种方法制作的最简单的产品通常是用碎肉制成的，例如汉堡包和鸡块。一些公司正在开发更具结构的产品，例如鸡胸肉和牛排。它们需要一个支架或细胞生长的结构，可以是植物性的，也可以是由胶原蛋白等动物产品制成的。

真的是肉吗？

专家表示，这是以不同方式制成的真正的肉。它与不含动物细胞的植物性产品（例如 Impossible 汉堡）不同。一些人造肉——包括 Good Meat 鸡肉产品——确实含有少量植物蛋白。 Upside Foods 的官员表示，他们的肉没有。

人们会买它吗？

优质食品研究所所长布鲁斯·弗里德里希 (Bruce Friedrich) 表示，在这种肉类的成本和口味与传统肉类相同之前，“它将保持小众市场”。另外，有些人觉得细胞肉的想法很奇怪。美联社和 NORC 公共事务研究中心最近进行的一项民意调查发现，一半的美国成年人表示他们不太可能尝试。当那些不太可能尝试的人被问及原因时，大约一半的人表示他们认为这不安全。世界卫生组织关于细胞食品的食品安全方面的报告指出了几个潜在的问题，例如过程中各个环节的微生物污染、生物残留物和副产品以及某些人可能过敏的脚手架。但专家指出，传统肉类也存在风险，例如屠宰和包装过程之前和过程中的细菌污染。

当外星人到来时，他们肯定会直接去 IMDB 调查她的电影作品，并想知道为什么好莱坞最有趣、最有魅力的明星之一在反乌托邦、动作片和任何你称之为“母亲！”的东西中度过了她职业生涯的第一个十年。

当然，我们有很多关于青少年试图第一次上床的电影。但由吉恩·斯图普尼茨基执导和联合编剧的《No Hard Feelings》可能是第一部，该青少年似乎无意这样做。他是异性恋，他的父母根据他的浏览历史确信他是异性恋。

但当玛蒂·巴克（劳伦斯饰）穿着粉色紧身连衣裙和高跟鞋出现在珀西（费尔德曼饰）工作的长岛动物收容所时，他对她的挑衅大多表现出刺痛和恐惧。这场遭遇以珀西用狼牙棒向麦迪喷洒而结束。

现在，一个 19 岁的女孩像这样拒绝詹妮弗·劳伦斯可能是切断观众与主角之一任何可能联系的好方法。这就像让他打孩子一样。有些事情是不可原谅的。麦迪和珀西进行了一系列日益亲密的约会，珀西发誓最终会“退出”。

总的来说，“没有难受”的基础是相当站不住脚的。比珀西对麦迪的反应更不可信的是她首先参与了这个计划。在电影的开场场景中，她的车被一个幽灵般的前男友拖走了-男朋友（《熊》中的 Ebon Moss-Bachrach）。在蒙托克的超级富裕地区，麦迪试图保住她的房子——她长大的房子——而取消抵押品赎回权却潜伏着。

麦迪被迫滑旱冰从事调酒工作，她可能在经济上陷入困境。但是，不管你对零工经济有什么看法，除了和那些因为餐厅没有百事可乐而感到畏缩的青少年上床之外，它还提供了很多赚钱的选择。

然而，“没有难受的感觉”的效果比应有的要好。这种荒谬的设置自然是笑话的一部分。费尔德曼在这里就像《料理鼠王》中笨拙的扁面条，给这个角色带来了比你想象的更敏感的感觉，并闪现出良好的喜剧时机。在他们的约会中，他感到非常不舒服，以至于当附近一场台球比赛中断时，他像一只受惊的猫一样跳了起来。他瘦弱地浸入大海，狗式划桨。

虽然这个角色迫使劳伦斯陷入不雅的境地，这很容易被认为是在她之下，但《没有难受的感觉》给了她足够的空间来展示她颠覆好莱坞魅力传统观念的才华。每时每刻，她都喜欢削弱自己的性感。并不是每个一线明星都愿意裸体拍摄海滩打斗场面。好莱坞编剧注意到，劳伦斯更擅长模仿性炸弹，而不是成为性炸弹。

然而，虽然《No Hard Feelings》最终为劳伦斯（也是一名执行制片人）提供了一个平台，让她可以展现她所擅长的一些闹剧幽默，但也感觉她已经被融入了一部相当男性化的成长浪漫的框架中—— com/幻想。如今，大银幕喜剧片少之又少，而且相距甚远，因此人们很容易为周五在影院上映的《没有难受的感觉》的存在而鼓掌。

斯图普尼茨基的《好孩子》巧妙地将一种熟悉的类型——家庭聚会电影——缩小为适合六年级学生的 R 级欢闹片。但《No Hard Feelings》可能会让人感觉陷入了青春期。有时候，你会很高兴劳伦斯至少能与成年人一起表演。（娜塔莉·莫拉莱斯和斯科特·麦克阿瑟是麦迪的好朋友。）劳伦斯本可以轻松地带着喜剧只达到麦迪的水平，没有业余护送孩子的故事情节。

不过，《No Hard Feelings》确实巧妙地挖掘了代沟，颠覆了该类型的标准节拍。珀西和他的许多同学被描述为过于依赖手机，而且过于敏感，无法察觉到冒犯。在一个场景中，麦迪拆毁了高中聚会的楼上大厅。每扇门后面都有孩子，他们没有亲热，而是平静地发短信或玩电子游戏——这是 Z 世代的写照，有充分的事实依据。玛蒂难以置信地惊呼道：“不再有人他妈的了吗？”

索尼影业发行的《No Hard Feelings》因色情内容、语言、一些裸露画面和简短的药物使用而被美国电影协会评为 R 级。片长：103分钟。两星半（满分四星）。

布鲁塞尔（美联社）——北约军事联盟负责人在接受美联社采访时表示，随着欧洲数十年来最大规模的陆地战争蹂躏乌克兰，北约在努力应对气候变化的同时确保其作战部队的有效性时面临着一系列困境。周三。

世界武装部队是碳氢化合物（燃料和石油）的最大消耗者之一，这些碳氢化合物会产生温室气体。近年来，由于资源和粮食短缺，全球变暖加剧了冲突和危机，对它们的需求量很大。

秘书长延斯·斯托尔滕贝格表示，北约面临的主要困境是“在绿色军队和强大军队之间做出艰难的选择”。

他说，北约需要“调和对一支有效、强大的武装部队的需求与对气候友好型武装部队的需求。”

去年，世界上最大的安全组织在其新战略概念（本质上是北约的使命宣言）中首次承认气候变化是“我们这个时代的决定性挑战，对盟军安全产生深远影响”。

该文件承认，31国联盟的“基础设施、资产和基地很容易受到其影响”。它警告说，北约军队被迫在更加极端的气候条件下行动，并越来越多地被要求参加救灾行动。

“气候变化是危机的倍增器。它加剧了对水和土地等稀缺资源的竞争，并迫使数百万人离开自己的国家。因此，所有这些都会影响我们的安全，”斯托尔滕贝格在布鲁塞尔北约总部告诉美联社。

上周，北约在德国开始了一次被称为该联盟历史上最大规模的空中部署演习。来自 25 个国家的约 250 架飞机（主要排放源）响应了针对北约成员国的模拟袭击。仅美国就派出了约100架飞机。

这次演习是计划已久的，但仍然是北约威慑和防御战略的一部分；它正在努力劝阻俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京不要将针对乌克兰的战争扩大到联盟的任何成员。兵棋推演不太可能停止。

斯托尔滕贝格表示，实现平衡的最佳方式是“发展技术并确保武装部队成为正在进行的能源转型的一部分。”北约设立了一个“创新基金”和一个气候变化卓越中心来帮助开发此类技术。

英国也开始在其部分飞机上使用更加气候友好的燃料——生物燃料。其他盟国正在研究减少对柴油的依赖的方法，柴油在运输过程中也特别容易受到空中或陆地攻击。

但斯托尔滕贝格表示，北约不能简单地“一举100%从化石技术转向零排放技术”。这就引发了另一个困境。

他说，“随着时间的推移，我们将拥有并行系统，这会增加成本，并且在物流方面会出现额外的问题”，当涉及到向发动机、主战坦克和舰船提供不同种类的燃料和零件时。

“另一个困境是确保这些系统能够协同工作，”斯托尔滕贝格说。 “如果不同国家（使用）不同的系统，部分是化石，部分是新技术，那么互换性和互操作性问题将更加困难。”

在俄罗斯去年入侵乌克兰之前，许多欧洲国家严重依赖俄罗斯的石油和天然气，因此在某种程度上，应对气候变化的斗争被推迟了。波兰等一些国家正在放慢从煤炭的转型，而比利时等其他国家则计划在更长时间内继续使用核能。

斯托尔滕贝格警告说，各国必须警惕对用于制造电池、太阳能电池板和风车的锂和钴等稀土矿物产生新的依赖，特别是对中国等独裁国家。

斯托尔滕贝格告诉美联社，安全是应对气候变化的核心，而和平是其先决条件，无论是在乌克兰还是其他地方。

他说，我们需要和平与稳定，这样各国才能相互合作，并在全球范围内做出有意义的减排努力。

他说：“如果盟友或乌克兰被迫在气候友好型部队和有效的武装部队之间做出选择，那么每个人都会选择一支强大而有效的军队，因为这关系到我们的安全。”斯托尔滕贝格强调，挑战“是从长远来看协调这两个目标”。

通常，会有一个明确的冠军：2017 年，Lusi Fonsi、Daddy Yankee 和 Justin Bieber 的“Despacito”是不可避免的。 2019 年，Lil Nas X 无处不在的“Old Town Road”预示着未来的超级巨星。奥利维亚·罗德里戈 (Olivia Rodrigo) 的《驾驶执照》在 2021 年也做了同样的事情。但情况并非总是如此。

如果他们不必这样做怎么办？好吧，以下是美联社对 2023 年夏季预测的歌曲以及往年各桂冠的持有者：

夏季俱乐部歌曲：Latto ft. Cardi B 的“Put It On Da Floor Again”

说唱歌手 Latto 在《Put It On Da Floor》中以热情、简约的节奏演绎出好斗、严肃的旋律，使其成为俱乐部夏季歌曲的有力竞争者。它还兼作季节性口号：“我在家里跳舞很性感/我感觉像布兰妮·斯皮尔斯，”嘉宾 Cardi B 吐槽道。

过去的冠军：碧昂丝的《Break My Soul》（2022 年）

一月份莫名其妙地出现的夏季歌曲： “Boy's a Liar PT.” 2”由 PinkPantheress、Ice Spice 创作

PinkPantheress 超级流行朋克和无精打采的说唱歌手 Ice Spice 的梦想二人组创作了“Boy's a Liar PT.”。 2”，这是一篇关于现代约会的论文，具有不可否认的吸引力，并且对“骗子”一词的发音非常有创意。 （那个男孩是……狮子座？） 很少有歌曲能有六个月以上的持久力，但很少有歌曲能挑战流行歌曲的听起来：太空感，有时，迷人的谦逊。就像摩羯座一样。

过去的冠军：太棒了，必须提到两次——奥利维亚·罗德里戈（Olivia Rodrigo）的《驾驶执照》（2021）

夏季的后讽刺、TikTok 重磅、在线微热门歌曲：That Chick Angel、Casa Di 和 Steve Terrell 创作的“The Margarita Song”

当你在大学校园里聆听一位自称“糖果姐妹”的女士关于“荡妇羞辱”的对抗性福音派布道时，将其重新混合并给它一个陷阱节奏，你会得到什么？感谢喜剧演员/说唱歌手安吉尔·莱克塔·摩尔 (Angel Laketa Moore) 以及艺术家卡尔·迪克森 (Carl Dixon ) 和史蒂夫·特雷尔 ( Steve Terrell)的大力支持。

过去的冠军：Cosmo Sheldrake 的《Birthday Suit》（2019 年）

热辣（离婚）女孩（夏日之歌）：麦莉·赛勒斯的《Flowers》

那些等待麦莉·赛勒斯 (Miley Cyrus)演唱的得克萨斯州大小的乡村歌曲的人将继续这样做，但与此同时：“Flowers”是一首 80 年代的合成摇滚，适合那些心碎的人——并克服它。对于赛勒斯来说，这是一首关于离婚后生活的歌曲，但对于她的粉丝来说，这是对自己找到伙伴关系的庆祝。

过去的冠军：Carly Pearce 的《Next Girl》（2020 年）

本周夏日之歌：凯莉·米洛 (Kylie Minogue) 的《Padam Padam》

就像夏日狂欢一样，凯莉·米洛 (Kylie Minogue) 的迪斯科心跳“Padam Padam”对于那些喜欢明亮、快速和强烈的歌曲的人来说是值得迷恋的流行音乐。

过去的冠军：Fifth Harmony 的“Work From Home”（2016 年）

年度最热门歌曲，因此也是夏季默认歌曲：摩根·沃伦 (Morgan Wallen) 的《Last Night》

摩根·沃伦 (Morgan Wallen) 的统治持续到了夏天，他的乡村流行摇滚分手唱片《最后一夜》(Last Night) 统治了地面广播——很可能也统治了你旁边的人的耳机。

前冠军：Gotye, Kimbra 的“Somebody That I Old to Know”（2011 年）

实际上是翻唱的夏日之歌：卢克·库姆斯 (Luke Combs) 的《Fast Car》

这位乡村明星将特雷西·查普曼的经典歌曲改编成北卡罗来纳州的篝火曲。非常适合开车，速度很快。

过去的冠军：乔纳斯·布鲁 (Jonas Blue)，达科他州 (2015) 的《Fast Car》——或者实际上是《Fast Car》的任何其他翻唱，过去和现在

斯威夫特夏季歌曲：泰勒·斯威夫特的《Karma》

简而言之：Karma 是我的男朋友，Karma 是神，这一季“Karma”无处不在……就像泰勒·斯威夫特 (Taylor Swift) 一样， 她的 Eras 巡演还在继续。

过去的冠军：泰勒·斯威夫特的《Red》（2013）

献给那些总是像夏天一样生活的人的歌曲：Bad Bunny 的“WHERE SHE GOES”

以“WHERE SHE GOES”这样的标题，波多黎各雷鬼乐队Bad Bunny似乎正准备发行一首用英语录制的跨界热门歌曲。但这不是他的风格。相反，贝尼托（Benito）（粉丝们亲切地称呼他为“贝尼托”）将 Dembow 和 Drill 的世界结合在一起，仍然用西班牙语演唱——非常适合深夜派对或随后的海滩清晨。

过去的冠军：J Balvin、Willy William 的“Mi Gente”（2017 年）

复仇之夏之歌：SZA 的《杀死比尔》

SZA 的风格矛盾的深情流行音乐在这个复仇幻想中达到了自我实现的新水平。 “我可能会杀了我的前任，”她低声说道，这是对她最坏冲动的温和驱魔。 “这不是最好的主意。”

前冠军：702 的《Where My Girls At》（1999 年）

适合今年夏天的单曲：Eslabon Armado x Peso Pluma 的“Ella Baila Sola”

还有比 Eslabon Armado 和 Peso Pluma 的热门歌曲《Ella Baila Sola》更成功的故事吗？墨西哥地方音乐已经进入美国主流——喇叭等等——这首关于一个女人独自跳舞的轻浮歌曲就是证明。

过去的冠军：T-Pain、Yung Joc 的“Buy You A Drank (Shawty Snappin')” (2007)

夏日浪漫之歌：雷玛、赛琳娜·戈麦斯的《Calm Down》

尼日利亚歌手 Rema 和流行歌星 Selena Gomez 创作的非洲节奏歌曲在这一季并没有放慢脚步。预计在海边的露天场所和当地的杂货店内都会听到同样的声音，但大多数情况下，是在后院亲热时安静地演奏。

过去的冠军：All-4-One 的“I Swear”（1994 年）

夏日赋能歌曲：Lil Durk ft. J. Cole 的《All My Life》

儿童合唱团、trap节拍和鼓舞人心的旋律使《All My Life》成为夏季让人感觉良好的歌曲，提醒人们积极的态度是一剂强效良药。

历届冠军：Lady Gaga 的《Born This Way》（2011 年）

夏日慢热歌曲：Toosii 的《最喜欢的歌曲》

香肠来来去去，但民谣却活在灵魂之中。说唱歌手 Toosii 的“最喜欢的歌曲”适合那些希望与所爱的人一起度过浪漫夏天的人们。

前冠军：Aaliyah 的《If Your Girl Only Knew》（1996 年）

适合悲伤女孩的夏日之歌：五十五十的《丘比特》

向独立流行乐队 Boygenius （菲比·布里杰斯、露西·达库斯和朱利安·贝克）的所有粉丝致歉，但今年夏天的悲伤女孩歌曲来自韩国流行女子乐队“五十五十”。他们失恋的泡泡糖流行歌曲《丘比特》中的和声像糖果一样甜蜜，适合摇下车窗并尖叫着跟着唱。

过去的冠军：Lana Del Rey 的《Summertime Sadness》（2012 年）

巴黎（美联社）——当局表示，周三，巴黎左岸一座建筑发生强烈爆炸，造成至少 24 人受伤，引发大火，烟雾在法国首都的纪念碑上空升腾，并促使其他建筑人员疏散。警方正在调查煤气泄漏引发爆炸的嫌疑。

第五区大楼外墙倒塌，官员称救援人员正在搜寻可能被困在里面的两人。爆炸发生在历史悠久的格雷斯谷军事医院附近，该医院位于法国首都最高档的社区之一。

约270名消防员参与灭火，70辆急救车被派往现场。周三晚上，大火已得到控制，但尚未扑灭，巴黎的酒吧和餐馆在全市范围内举办一年一度的音乐节来庆祝夏至。

当救护车经过该街区时，警笛鸣响，警方最初封锁了圣雅克街。到了晚上，发生爆炸的大楼不再冒烟。

内政部长杰拉尔德·达尔马宁在现场表示：“我们有可能在一夜之间发现尸体或活着的人。”

区长 Florence Berthout 在法国电视频道 BFM 上表示，消防队员正在搜寻爆炸时据信在大楼内的两名人员。 “爆炸非常猛烈，”她描述说，玻璃碎片仍然从建筑物上掉落。

巴黎警察局长洛朗·努涅斯表示，这座建筑内有一所私立学校，即巴黎美国学院。学校成立于1965年，提供时装设计、室内设计、美术和创意写作方面的教学。

巴黎警方一名官员告诉美联社，共有24人受伤，其中4人伤势严重，20人伤势较轻。这位官员表示，受伤的原因主要是人们被爆炸炸倒。

爆炸现场附近拥有一家肉店的杰玛·哈尔伯特 (Jema Halbert) 说，她上楼去拿东西，“我听到‘轰’的一声。 ……然后我下楼，发现我的丈夫很震惊，收银台上满是灰尘，我想，等等，有问题。所以我走到外面，看到大火，我说，这是不可能的。我打电话给我女儿。她在哭。她很震惊。”

第五区副区长爱德华·西维尔(Edouard Civel)将爆炸归因于煤气泄漏，但其他官员则更为谨慎。一名司法官员表示，瓦斯爆炸是正在调查的可能原因之一。

著名的希腊裔法国电影制片人科斯塔-加夫拉斯是现场的目击者之一。

这位 90 岁的老人告诉美联社：“一声巨大的噪音，房子像这样摇晃起来。”“我们想，发生了什么事？我们认为可能是天空（一场暴风雨）...... ……这不是什么值得笑的事情。”

巴黎检察官表示，已对严重非自愿伤害展开调查，调查将调查爆炸是否源于涉嫌违反安全规则。检察官劳尔·贝库奥表示，调查人员将寻求“确定是否存在不遵守规则或个人轻率导致爆炸的情况”。

努涅斯说，消防队员阻止了大火点燃邻近的两座建筑物，这两座建筑物因爆炸而“严重不稳定”，必须疏散。目击者和警察局长说，爆炸炸毁了该地区的几扇窗户。

巴黎市区内人口密集，基础设施历史悠久，有时甚至老化，瓦斯爆炸对巴黎来说并不陌生。 2019 年 1 月，第九区发生爆炸，造成 4 人死亡、数十人受伤。

周三爆炸发生后，该私立学校的一名学生表示，爆炸发生时他正在约 100 米外的一栋建筑内。

“我坐在窗台上，我们离开窗户 2 米，伴随着一阵小爆炸（爆炸）和巨大的恐惧，”阿奇勒（未透露姓氏）告诉 BFM 电视台。

“我们（从大楼）下来看到了火焰，”他说。“警察给了我们很大的支持，我们很快就撤离了。”

欧盟执行机构负责人、欧盟委员会主席乌苏拉·冯德莱恩表示，新一揽子计划将“通过收紧出口限制，针对支持克里姆林宫的实体，进一步打击普京的战争机器。”

PARIS (AP) — Unveiling a new chapter in its illustrious history, Louis Vuitton made an indelible mark on Paris Fashion Week's men's shows as they premiered the debut collection by musician-turned-designer Pharrell Williams.

Appointed in February to fill the immense shoes left by the death of Virgil Abloh, Williams unveiled his design prowess to the fashion world with a show that exuded confidence.

The breathtaking venue for this sartorial spectacle was Paris' iconic Pont Neuf. The historic bridge, typically resplendent with time-worn stone, was transformed into a golden runway — a dramatic stage set against the backdrop of the shimmering Seine and under the starlit Parisian sky.

The Tuesday night event drew a constellation of stars in their own right. The stellar audience encompassed icons of music, sports and entertainment. Among the guests lining the gilded cobbles were music royalty Beyoncé and Jay-Z, NBA superstar LeBron James, new brand ambassador Zendaya and global pop phenomenon Rihanna.

Williams' first show proved to be an ambitious endeavor, interweaving the luxury and sophistication of high fashion with the pulsating energy and broad appeal of pop culture and entertainment. The show was more than a runway presentation; it was an immersive experience that captured the imagination of those fortunate enough to witness it firsthand.

Here are some highlights of the spring-summer 2024 shows:

PHARRELL SPEAKS

As sunlight filled the storied halls of Louis Vuitton's headquarters, Williams stepped into his new role as the fashion house's menswear designer.

His appointment symbolizes more than a career shift. It represents a daring move by the luxury brand to entrust the position to a musical artist and cultural influencer, not a classically trained designer. But Pharrell says he doesn't feel pressure to prove himself — he was chosen.

“I didn't feel any of that because if I was competing for it and people kept telling me, 'No don't do it,' I may have felt that way. But the difference is, I was chosen,” Pharrell told AP in a joint interview. "So, like when you're chosen, you just kind of ride the wave.”

A sense of being selected by the universe, or by Louis Vuitton, carries a sense of destiny for him. But stepping into the designer role isn't just about fulfilling his personal destiny. Williams also feels like he's carrying on the legacy of the late Abloh, who was the first Black artistic director at Louis Vuitton and a personal friend. “My appointment is a tribute,” Williams said.

Black culture and the struggles Black Americans have faced is a strong driving force for Pharrell. He reflected on the culture's unique flavor, influence and widespread appeal. “I think it's something in the sauce,” he said. “And people like it when they try it.”

Williams emphasized the hard-earned global recognition of this cultural “sauce,” exemplified in the influence of figures like LeBron James, Jay-Z, Beyoncé, Prince and artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.

“A lot of people lost their lives and suffered through the experiences to get us to these positions,” he noted, underscoring the painful history that fuels his desire to honor his community through his work at Louis Vuitton.

Pharrell's love for life, the moment, and opportunities, imbue his approach to design. “LV is for Louis Vuitton, but it's also 'lover',” he mused. His interpretation of the Louis Vuitton initials signifies his intention to pour love and appreciation into his work, carrying the legacy of Black culture forward in a space where it has been historically underrepresented.

“It's not lost on me that I'm afforded this opportunity to tell these stories,” he said.

LOUIS VUITTON SHOW

The pulse of Paris was set alight as Williams unveiled a debut fusing streetwear aesthetics into the French maison's traditional lineage. The fashion show epitomized high-voltage energy, reverberating through the audience and culminating in a standing ovation for Williams.

The world-renowned musician, known for his genre-blurring creativity, masterfully orchestrated the event. The runway show mirrored a music video's high energy, perhaps a testament to the meteoric reach of the brand's parent company, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton.

Channeling gender-fluid appeal, Williams showcased an exhaustive collection spanning checkerboard-patterned denim to a sophisticated cream evening jacket. The line, marked by photo prints of the Pont Neuf and a uniquely designed coat with a shaved monogram motif, also underscored his flair for distinct aesthetics.

Playing on the LV codes, Williams' collaboration with American pixel artist ET for a digital motif and the use of Black American artist Henry Taylor's micro-embroideries added a further dimension to his debut lineup. The collection was replete with pixelated designs on a broad spectrum of pieces, alongside the Damier pattern — which graces the house's bags — amplified in shades of yellow and black.

The grand finale was a spectacular concert by Jay-Z. The electrifying performance brought the crowd to its feet, their excitement reaching a crescendo as Pharrell took to the stage to join his longtime collaborator. While Rihanna's arrival, in sync with the show's climax and exposing a enormous bare baby bump, was nothing short of theatrical.

As the show drew to a close, an emotional Williams emerged to take a bow, wiping away tears and pointing skyward in a heartfelt thank you. The applause that followed was a thunderous affirmation of the musician's successful transition into the realm of luxury fashion.

CHANEL RESORT

After the pulsating late-night Vuitton showcase, a more subdued morning scene unfolded at Chanel's headquarters. Members of the fashion press gathered, copious servings of coffee and croissants in hand, to view a breakfast presentation of Chanel's resort collection. Thus began the glamorous marathon that is Paris Fashion Week.

Themes from Hollywood's Golden Age characterized designer Virginie Viard's collection, incorporating hints at the 1920s and 1930s. They were transfused with a distinct 1980s influence in sequins and vibrant color.

Viard presented a long, loose coat, a style staple one might associate with film producers of the art deco era. Furthering the Hollywood motif, a lace A-line mini dress took its bleeding color palette from an LA sunset, a nod to Sunset Boulevard. Additionally, a ruched tiered skirt carried the pink and white stripe pattern commonly associated with the Beverly Hills Hotel.

The resort collection's encore in Paris provided an opportunity for a closer inspection of Viard's Hollywood-inspired designs and the detailing involved without the breathlessness of a glitzy show. Amidst the rapid progression of fashion, Chanel's collection served as a reminder of the brand's engagement with historic and pop culture references.

BOTTER'S QUIRKS

The design duo behind the Botter label, Rushemy Botter and Lisi Herrebrugh, are known for their progressive and bold approach to fashion. The spring-summer collection they presented Wednesday showcased a series of daring and inventive interpretations of everyday elements.

Ecological plastic wicker, typically found on chairs was cleverly reconfigured into garments. The unconventional material was particularly affecting in a bright red structured vest red that resembled chainmail, demonstrating Botter's creative — and quirky — reinterpretation of commonplace items.

The designs also included distinctive lozenge motifs that gave a slightly historical impression, especially on skintight tops and tights-cum-leggings that at times reassembled the look of a medieval peasant.

In a contrast to the quirky designs, a delicate lavender knit vest unfurled like a disintegrating flower, adding a touch of poetic elegance to a pair of baggy charcoal office pants, a testament to Botter's versatility.

While their designs tend to be daring and offbeat, the y manage to strike a balance between the surreal and wearable, maintaining their appeal to a forward-thinking audience.

BLUEMARBLE DAZZLES WITH COLOR

Designer Anthony Alvarez didn't shy away from color in his menswear collection for Bluemarble. His vibrant palette was a delightful mix of citrine and dandelion. The unstructured and utilitarian designs combined streetwear sensibilities with a dash of high-fashion daring. Toggles that were part practical, part design statement, flapped in an unexpectedly fashionable sync with the collection's aesthetic rhythm.

The choice of shades on the models, and the satiny dazzle on coats, lent a sunshine-bathed charisma to the show, aptly reflecting the “blue marble” — planet Earth — that inspired the brand's name. Bleached blond hair and curtains subtly echoed the late-80s, while the boxy silhouettes seemed like a contemporary nod to the iconic era.

Building on Bluemarble's reputation for eye-popping color and cultural fusion, Alvarez balanced the mix of his own diverse heritage in his designs. (He was raised by a French mother and a Filipino-Spanish father.) The collection not only celebrated his brand's globe-trotting vision but elevated it with bold colors, strategic nostalgia, and streetwise utility.

LOUIS GABRIEL NOUCHI BRINGS VIBRANT TRANSFORMATION IN MENSWEAR

In his Wednesday evening show, Louis Gabriel Nouchi masterfully blended conventional sartorial elements with sportswear.

The collection opened with a striking, voluminous black leather trench coat, which displayed Asiatic layering influences. The initial monochrome black and dark tones, set a somber, yet anticipative, stage.

Ubiquitous ties, crisp white shirts, and black leather loafers then formed a staple backbone. This familiar territory was thrillingly disrupted by deconstructed vests and cycling pants, demonstrating Nouchi's knack for challenging boundaries.

The dark musing soon transformed into a visual spectacle of eye-catching hues – straw and light cobalt blue – conjuring a playful disruption. The zenith arrived with a show-stopping ensemble: a loose tie-pajama look rendered in daring, dazzling sapphire.

Building on previous seasons' play with silhouettes, particularly the emphasized shoulder line, and explorations into various materials such as leather.

DENVER (AP) — Months after Colorado's voters decided to join Oregon in decriminalizing psychedelic mushrooms, Denver is hosting a conference this week put on by a psychedelic advocacy group bringing together an unlikely cohort of speakers — including an NFL star, a former Republican governor and a rapper.

The conference and the thousands attending is an indication of the creep, or perhaps leap, of cultural acceptance for psychedelic substances that proponents say may offer benefits for things like post-traumatic stress disorder and alcoholism. Still, medical experts caution that more research is needed on the drugs' efficacy and the extent of the risks of psychedelics, which can cause hallucinations.

NFL quarterback Aaron Rodgers, who'll soon debut with the New York Jets after years with the Green Bay Packers, will speak with a podcaster Wednesday evening about his ayahuasca experience and how he believes it helped his game. Rapper and actor Jaden Smith, the son of Will Smith who has publicly shared the “ego dissolution” he felt when using psychedelics, will speak, too. Former Texas Republican Gov. TURMUS AYYA, West Bank (AP) — Hundreds of Israeli settlers stormed into a Palestinian town in the occupied West Bank on Wednesday, setting fire to dozens of cars and homes to avenge the deaths of four Israelis killed by Palestinian gunmen the previous day, residents said. Palestinians said one man was killed in the violence.

After nightfall, Israel carried out a rare airstrike on a car carrying suspected Palestinian gunmen in the West Bank. The drone strike, believed to be the first in the area in nearly 20 years, marked a major escalation by Israel in a more than year-long campaign against militants in the area. Palestinian media reported three were killed in the strike.

The fighting further raised tensions heightened this week by a daylong Israeli military raid that killed seven people, including a 15-year-old girl, in a militant stronghold, and Tuesday's mass shooting, whose victims included a 17-year-old Israeli boy.

Wednesday's settler rampage came as the Israeli military deployed additional forces in the occupied West Bank, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to build 1,000 new settler homes in response to the deadly shooting.

Palestinian residents and human rights groups have long complained about Israel's inability or refusal to halt settler violence. Residents in Turmus Ayya said some 400 settlers marched down the town's main road, setting fire to cars, homes and trees.

Mayor Lafi Adeeb said some 30 houses and 60 cars were partly or totally burned. At least eight Palestinians were hurt during clashes, which the army tried to disperse by firing rubber bullets and tear gas.

Palestinian medical officials said one man — identified as 27-year-old Omar Qatin — was killed by army fire. Residents said Qatin was a father of two small children and worked as an electrician for the local municipality.

Israeli police said they were attacked by residents with rocks and fireworks. It said one officer opened fire after believing his life was in danger, hitting a “rioter.” But Palestinian residents disputed the account.

“He was just standing there, innocent, he is such a kind-hearted kid. He had no stones, he was totally unarmed, he was at least half a mile (one kilometer) away from the military,” said Khamis Jbara, his neighbor. “He works from 6am to 6pm. He is a peaceful man.”

The town's Palestinian residents, including many who are American citizens, were seething and in shock after the attack.

Streets were littered with broken pots, uprooted trees, charred yard furniture and skeletons of cars. At least one house was completely torched, the living room blackened, the furniture burned to ashes.

“It was terrifying, we just saw mobs of people in the streets, masked, armed,” said Mohammed Suleiman, a 56-year-old Palestinian-American who lives in Chicago and was visiting his hometown.

Suleiman blamed the Israeli military, saying the soldiers turned their guns on the Palestinian residents instead of the vandals marching into the town with guns and firebombs and setting alight everything in their path. The army was "literally clearing the way for them,” he said.

Abdulkarim Abdulkarim, a 44-year-old resident of Ohio, said his family's four cars were burned and house damaged. “They call us terrorists but here you have terrorism supported by the government,” he said.

In the home of the Shalaby family, eight children hid on the third floor when they saw a mob of masked settlers slash tires and throw fuel on three cars. Within moments, their front yard erupted into a giant fireball. At least one of the armed settlers burst through the front door, trashing the sunroom and breaking windows.

“I just kept thinking I was going to die,” said 15-year-old Mohammed Awwad, an American citizen from northern California who was visiting his grandparents. He was removing pieces of glass from his foot as his family packed up their valuables to take to an aunt's house in the hills, fearing the settlers' return.

Turmus Ayya, a town with luxurious villas with gardens and views of rolling olive groves, is frequently a target of settler attacks. Tayem Abu Awwad, whose old car was torched in a separate attack last week, said his brand new Toyota was charred in Wednesday's rampage.

The Israeli military said it sent forces into the town “to extinguish the fires, prevent clashes and to collect evidence.”

The military condemned “these serious incidents of violence and destruction of property," adding that settler violence prevents it from carrying out its “main mission” of protecting national security and battling militants.

But later Wednesday, further norther in the town of Urif, an angry mob of some 100 settlers ran through the town, throwing rocks at Palestinian homes and hurling a firebomb at the local school, said local Palestinian official Ghassan Daghlas. Palestinian residents said Israeli security forces fired live bullets, stun grenades and tear gas at them as they tried to fend off the settlers.

Just as settlers were withdrawing from the town, the Israeli drone hit the Palestinian car near the militant stronghold of Jenin, turning the vehicle into a fireball.

The identities of the people on board were not immediately known. But the army said it had “identified a terrorist cell inside a suspicious vehicle” that had been responsible for a number of recent shooting attacks on Jewish settlements.

Ismail Radwan, a leader in the Hamas militant group, called the drone strike a “dangerous development” and called on “the resistance in the West Bank to escalate the confrontation.”

The settler attack brought back memories of a rampage last February in which dozens of cars and homes were torched in the town of Hawara following the killing of a pair of Israeli brothers by a Palestinian gunman.

Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh visited Turmus Ayya to inspect the damage. Local criticism of the Palestinian Authority has intensified over its weakness in the face of settler attacks.

As he spoke, expressing solidarity with the residents and appealing to the United States to intervene — given the high percentage of American citizens in the town — one resident shouted at him and demanded the authority “do more to protect its people.”

Egypt and Jordan, the first two Arab countries to make peace with Israel, both condemned the settler violence and called for an immediate end to the attacks.

Netanyahu criticized the settler violence, as well as unrelated protests by Druze Arabs in the Golan Heights that turned violent.

“We will not accept any provocations to the police or the security forces in these places or anywhere else,” he said. “We are a nation of laws.”

Tuesday's shooting in the settlement of Eli came a day after seven Palestinians were killed in a battle against Israeli troops in Jenin. The worsening violence has created a test for Israel's government and prompted calls for a widespread military operation in the West Bank.

巴蒂尔，约旦河西岸（美联社）——几代巴勒斯坦人在耶路撒冷西南部这个约旦河西岸农村的梯田山坡上耕作，在与圣经中的大卫王相连的山谷中种植橄榄、水果、豆类和精美的茄子，在该地区享有盛誉。

但居民们担心，随着以色列极右翼政府在附近山顶上推进定居点项目，他们古老的生活方式可能很快就会受到威胁。环保组织表示，该建筑可能会破坏供应农业梯田的本已紧张的水源，并对本已岌岌可危的生态系统造成广泛破坏。

巴蒂尔的困境揭示了以色列-巴勒斯坦冲突的外在因素——定居点、土地争端和军事活动——如何对该地区的环境、自然资源和文化遗产造成损害。

58 岁的拉希德·奥维纳 (Rashid Owinah) 说，拟议的建设“将占用大量土地，而且你不知道它会在哪里结束”，他的家人世代在巴蒂尔务农。 “这将在精神、经济和社会方面影响社区。”

EcoPeace 和自然保护协会这两个环保组织已请求以色列当局停止该计划，理由是它可能会对下面郁郁葱葱的梯田花园造成影响。

在圣经记载大卫与非利士人作战的山谷中，这里的一些地方似乎没有受到现代社会的干扰，农民们从一个拥有 2000 年历史的罗马时代水池引水，在顺山而下的梯田上种植庄稼。

最近的一天，水从岩石表面喷涌而出，顺着结果桑树下的渡槽流向下方废弃的奥斯曼火车轨道，这条轨道曾经将梯田的农产品运往耶路撒冷。

虽然哈尔吉洛定居点的扩建早已记录在案， 但总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡领导的新极端民族主义和宗教政府已将此类项目列为首要任务。当地定居者领袖正在努力推动该计划成为现实。

2014 年，联合国文化遗产机构联合国教科文组织将巴蒂尔周围蛇形山谷中具有千年历史的梯田认定为世界遗产。

根据提交给联合国教科文组织的文件，“这种复杂的供水灌溉系统导致了干墙梯田的产生，这些梯田可能自古以来就被利用了”。 “这个传统供水系统的完整性得到了依赖它的 Battir 家庭的保证。”

在梯田和旨在保护它们的周围缓冲区之间，联合国教科文组织文化景观构成了大约 10 平方公里（3.8 平方英里）的丘陵和河谷。野餐者留下的塑料垃圾散落在穿过山谷的小路上。

这些梯田世代用作耶路撒冷和伯利恒的市场花园，由村里的农民共用的错综复杂的渡槽和渠道灌溉。据前市长阿克拉姆·巴德 (Akram Bader) 称，巴蒂尔 (Battir) 的 5,000 名居民中约有 40% 以务农为生。

“在这里，我们拒绝使用新机器，”他说。 “我们希望保留传统的农业方式。”

环保人士说，以色列计划在毗邻梯田的缓冲区建设定居点，这些泉水将受到威胁。

未来的定居点计划被称为 Har Gilo West，计划在 Battir 北部的山谷中开发一个不到 1 英里（1.5 公里）的崎岖山顶。该项目实际上将使现有 Har Gilo 定居点的面积扩大一倍，开始时将在俯瞰梯田的山脊上建造 560 个新住房单元。

Gush Etzion 定居点委员会主席 Shlomo Ne'eman 表示，该地区住房严重短缺，尤其是 Har Gilo。他说所有的城市发展都是以牺牲环境为代价的，但就哈尔吉洛西而言，他认为它位于“没有自然价值的岩石山顶”。

“没有泉水，没有森林，没有珍稀植物，”尼曼说，并指责环保组织的选择性政治活动。

他坚持认为，Har Gilo West 计划“不靠近梯田，不要接近它们，不要伤害它们，也不要触摸它们。”

以色列自然保护协会在其请愿书中表示，该计划“不符合任何环境标准”并且缺乏标准的环境评估文件。

它在该地点进行的一项夏季调查发现，至少有 195 种植物、25 种蝴蝶和许多鸟类，其中至少三种被列为濒危物种，并称这里是濒临灭绝的山瞪羚和受威胁的条纹鬣狗的栖息地。

负责被占约旦河西岸民政事务的以色列军事机构 COGAT 表示，现有计划旨在“尽量减少对景观的破坏，并（关注）其他环境问题。”它表示，该计划将审查环保组织提出的反对意见，但没有说明何时会发生。

以色列在 1967 年的中东战争中占领了约旦河西岸以及东耶路撒冷和加沙地带。巴勒斯坦人寻求这些领土以建立未来的独立国家。

大多数国际社会认为以色列定居点是与以色列一起建立一个可行的巴勒斯坦国的障碍。现在有超过 700,000 名犹太定居者居住在东耶路撒冷和约旦河西岸的数十个定居点。

由于强烈反对其对野生动物和生态系统的潜在影响，此前计划在梯田附近建造一段以色列西岸隔离墙的计划被取消。

以色列反定居点组织 Peace Now 的 Yonathan Mizrachi 表示，Har Gilo West 计划已经通过了拜占庭式定居点批准程序的几个步骤。

尽管该计划在推土机开进之前仍在等待最终批准，但他表示，去年 9 月批准的 Har Gilo 高速公路扩建表明以色列打算向前推进。

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras (AP) — Gang members in a women's prison in Honduras slaughtered 46 other women inmates by spraying them with gunfire, hacking them with machetes and then locking survivors in their cells and dousing them with flammable liquid, an official said Wednesday.

The carnage in Tuesday's riot was the worst atrocity at a women's prison in recent memory, something President Xiomara Castro called “monstrous.”

Relatives said inmates at the facility had been threatened for weeks by members of the notorious Barrio 18 gang.

Chillingly, the gang members were able to arm themselves with prohibited weapons, brush past guards and attack; they even carried locks to shut their victims inside, apparently to burn them to death. The intensity of the fire left the walls of the cells blackened and beds reduced to twisted heaps of metal.

“A group of armed people went to the cellblock of a rival gang, locked the doors, opened fire on them," said Juan López Rochez, the chief of operations for the country's National Police.

Miguel Martínez, a security ministry spokesman, said the attack was taped by security cameras, up to the moment the gang members destroyed them in what he called a “planned” attack.

“You can see the moment in which the women overcome the guards, leaving them helpless, and take their keys,” Martínez said.

Castro said Tuesday's riot at the prison in the town of Tamara, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) northwest of Honduras' capital, was “planned by maras (street gangs) with the knowledge and acquiescence of security authorities.”

Castro fired Security Minister Ramón Sabillón, and replaced him with Gustavo Sánchez, who had been serving as head of the National Police.

But Castro but did not explain how inmates identified as members of the Barrio 18 gang were able to get guns and machetes into the prison, or move freely into an adjoining cell block. Initial reports suggested the doors to the gang's cell block had been left open, facilitating the attack.

The amount of weaponry found in the prison after the riot was impressive: 18 pistols, an assault rifle, two machine pistols and two grenades — all of which were smuggled into the prison.

“Obviously, there must have been human failures,” López Rochez said. “We are investigating all the employees at the center.”

Sandra Rodríguez Vargas, the assistant commissioner for Honduras' prison system, said the attackers “removed” guards at the facility — none appeared to have been injured — around 8 am Tuesday.

帮派有时会通过提供帮派的姓名、地址和描述来要求受害者“交出”朋友或亲戚，以便执法人员以后可以找到并绑架、抢劫或杀死他们。

官员们将杀戮描述为“恐怖主义行为”，但也承认帮派基本上控制了监狱的某些部分。

帮派在该国监狱内拥有广泛的控制权，囚犯通常会制定自己的规则并出售违禁品。

Rescuers on Wednesday rushed more ships and vessels to the area where a submersible disappeared on its way to the Titanic wreckage site, hoping underwater sounds they detected for a second straight day might help narrow their search in an increasingly urgent mission.

Crews were scouring an area twice the size of Connecticut in waters 2 1/2 miles deep, said Captain Jamie Frederick of the First Coast Guard District, who noted that authorities are still holding out hope of saving the five passengers onboard the Titan.

“This is a search and rescue mission, 100%,” he said. ”... We'll continue to put every available asset that we have in an effort to find the Titan and the crew members.”

But even those who expressed optimism warned that many obstacles remain : from pinpointing the vessel's location, to reaching it with rescue equipment, to bringing it to the surface — assuming it's still intact. And all that has to happen before the passengers' oxygen supply runs out, which some have estimated might happen as early as Thursday morning.

Meanwhile, newly uncovered allegations suggest there had been significant warnings made about vessel safety during the submersible's development.

The area of the North Atlantic where the Titan went missing on Sunday is prone to fog and stormy conditions, making it an extremely challenging environment to conduct a search-and-rescue mission, said Donald Murphy, an oceanographer who served as chief scientist of the Coast Guard's International Ice Patrol. The lost submersible could be as deep as about 12,500 feet (3,800 meters) below the surface near the watery tomb of the Titanic.

Key to the search are camera-equipped remote-operated robots, which are designed to scan the seafloor in real-time at depths other vessels can't reach. Two were operating in the area Wednesday and more were on the way, officials said.

Frederick said while the sounds that have been detected offered a chance to narrow the search, their exact location and source hasn't yet been determined.

"We don't know what they are, to be frank,” he said.

Retired Navy Capt. Carl Hartsfield, now the director of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Systems Laboratory, said the sounds have been described as “banging noises,” but he warned that search crews “have to put the whole picture together in context and they have to eliminate potential manmade sources other than the Titan.”

The report was encouraging to some experts because submarine crews unable to communicate with the surface are taught to bang on their submersible's hull to be detected by sonar.

A US Navy official said during a media briefing Wednesday that a special naval salvage system that could be used to pull the Titan to the surface has arrived in St. John's, Canada, but it is expected to take another 24 hours to prepare it for use. The Navy said in a statement that the equipment is capable of hoisting “large, bulky and heavy undersea objects such as aircraft or small vessels."

“I think some people believe that because modern technology is so good, that you can do things like this and not have accidents, but that's just not the case," he said.

WASHINGTON (AP) — The special counsel who investigated the FBI's probe of ties between Russia and Donald Trump's 2016 campaign found himself at the center of a heated political fight as he appeared before a congressional committee Wednesday, with Democrats denouncing his inquiry and Republicans arguing that its findings helped prove an anti-Trump bias within law enforcement.

John Durham, the Justice Department special counsel who recently completed his report, testified before the House Judiciary Committee in a hearing that unfolded against the backdrop of a 37-count indictment of Trump on charges he illegally retained classified documents.

Despite roughly six hours of testimony, the hearing broke little new ground. Under questioning from Republicans, he repeated many of the strongest findings of condemnation in his 306-page report and also faced criticism from Democrats over a four-year investigation that produced just one conviction and fell short of Trump's claims that it would expose “the crime of the century.”

The hearing spotlighted well-established law enforcement errors during the years-old Trump-Russia investigation, but Durham's appearance took on more contemporary political resonance in light of the criminal case against Trump and efforts by the former president and some Republican allies to undermine public confidence in the FBI.

“They're never going to stop. Seven years of attacking Trump is scary enough, but what's more frightening, any one of us could be next,” said the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio.

Rep. Wesley Hunt, R-Texas, said Americans believe there's a “two-tiered system of justice” that, he said, was “terrifying."

“Here we are seven years later, still talking about President Trump and this Democrat-invented scandal,” Hunt said.

Democrats, for their part, went after Durham and his investigation in personal terms — Rep. Ted Lieu of California derided him for behaving like a “partisan hack.” They accused Republicans of using Durham's appearance as a pretext to criticize the FBI for its continued scrutiny of Trump and to distract from the former president's current legal troubles.

“That's why you're here today, not because of anything that happened in 2016,” New York Rep. Jerrold Nadler, the top Democrat on the committee, told Durham.

Durham, who was appointed by then-Attorney General William Barr to review the origins of Trump-Russia investigation, tried to keep the focus of the hearing on his findings.

He noted that his review found that FBI investigators examining potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia ignored exculpatory evidence, used a largely discredited dossier of opposition research to obtain a surveillance warrant on a former Trump campaign aide , withheld key information from judges and lacked an adequate basis to open a full investigation in the first place.

He said the errors in the investigation were notable because the inquiry was not a “run-of-the-mill investigation” but instead concerned a “presidential campaign."

He said current and former FBI agents had personally apologized to him for the way the Russia investigation was conducted.

“It's so highly sensitive, it could affect the outcome of a presidential election and the future of the nation,” Durham said. "You would expect that the discipline that would have been followed would have been higher than ever. And that didn't happen here. There's a sort of analytical rigor, the discipline in how we investigate criminal matters, that was just absent here in large measure.”

Democrats repeatedly steered the hearing back to Durham's track record, the abrupt and publicly unexplained departure of his top deputy , and the fact that many of his more damning findings were already revealed years earlier in a Justice Department inspector general report. His investigation yielded just one guilty plea from a little-known FBI lawyer, a case referred to his office by the inspector general. And the two cases that Durham's team took to trial ended in swift jury acquittals.

In a tense exchange, Rep. Steve Cohen, D-Tenn., tried to portray Durham as a prosecutor lacking legal standing and integrity who was attempting to protect Trump and his campaign for president.

“You had a good reputation, that's why the two Democrats supported you,” Cohen said, referring to the Democratic senators from Connecticut who had backed Durham's nomination for US attorney. “But the longer you hold on to Mr. Barr and this report that Mr. Barr gave you as special counsel, your reputation will be damaged as everybody's reputation who gets involved with Donald Trump will get damaged.”

Durham responded: “My concern about my reputation is with the people who I respect and my family and my Lord and I'm perfectly comfortable with my reputation with them, sir.”

GOP animosity toward the Justice Department was further fueled by Tuesday's announcement that President Joe Biden's son Hunter will likely avoid jail time in a plea deal on tax and gun allegations. Jordan tweeted that it was a “DOUBLE STANDARD OF JUSTICE."

The bureau also is facing bipartisan criticism of how it handles intelligence collected electronically under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, which allows spy agencies to collect foreign phone calls and e-mails for their investigations.

“Rules and laws need to be changed so that these mechanisms cannot be used again in this way to really harm the American public,” he said.

Connecticut Rep. Jim Himes, the panel's top Democrat, said after the committee's meeting that Durham didn't recommend any changes to existing law but broadly discussed the issues in the report and the handling of politically sensitive investigations.

“Our hearing was not political. Nobody was looking to score points,” Himes said. “People asked questions that indicated their political affiliation, but that's because they were doing due diligence around things that concern them.”

FBI Director Chris Wray has acknowledged errors in the Trump-Russia probe. In a statement Tuesday, the bureau said it had “ already implemented dozens of corrective actions , which have now been in place for some time."

The Durham report "reinforces the importance of ensuring the FBI continues to do its work with the rigor, objectivity, and professionalism the American people deserve and rightly expect,” the statement said.

这种骄傲伴随着痛苦，对于总统的家人来说，两者都已公开展示。共和党人一直在努力利用亨特·拜登的行为——以及他公认的毒瘾斗争——作为试图拖累他父亲的支柱。

作为父母，乔·拜登试图让儿子保持亲近；他们几乎每天都在说话。亨特最近去爱尔兰旅行时陪在他父亲身边，在白宫的草坪上与其他家庭成员一起参加复活节彩蛋卷，并在女儿上个月大学毕业时与他的父母一起在看台上。

但在公众看来， 为期五年的刑事调查即将结束，周二宣布了一项认罪协议，解决了对总统二儿子的税收和外国业务交易的调查。与司法部达成的协议意味着亨特·拜登将承认轻罪，只要他遵守在法庭上同意的条件，他将避免作为吸毒者非法持有枪支的更严重的重罪指控。

作为总统，乔·拜登 (Joe Biden) 强调要与联邦对其儿子交易的调查保持距离。

他能做的最慈父般的事情——建议一个儿子度过艰难时期——对于一个同时调查他儿子和他的政治对手的政府指挥办公室的人来说，并不完全可用。

“拜登总统总是把家人放在第一位，这给我留下了深刻的印象，”拜登家族的密友、特拉华州参议员克里斯·库恩斯说。 “在这起涉及亨特·拜登的案件中，他划清了界限。他没有参与或干涉司法部长达五年的调查，该调查现已接近尾声。我只能想象他们在能够向前迈进时可能会感到如释重负。”

但共和党人对结果并不满意，尤其是当司法部在一个不相关的案件中起诉前总统唐纳德特朗普时，他被指控处理机密文件不当。众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 将亨特·拜登 (Hunter Biden) 案的结果与目前正送交联邦法院的特朗普文件案进行了比较，并表示，“如果你是总统的儿子，你会得到一笔甜心交易。”

尽管亨特·拜登是一名普通公民，但他在过去五年的重要政治时刻中扮演了重要角色：在针对特朗普的第一起弹劾案中作为中心人物出现，特朗普试图让乌克兰的沃洛德米尔·泽伦斯基宣布对年轻的拜登相关人员进行调查到他在一家乌克兰天然气公司董事会的职位。

亨特·拜登 (Hunter Biden) 的弟弟博·拜登 (Beau Biden) 于 2015 年因癌症去世后，亨特·拜登 (Hunter Biden) 陷入了毒品和酗酒的泥潭，导致了一些令人不安的决定和干预措施， 共和党人将这些决定和干预措施作为他阴暗策略的证据，但他也不总是能自救。

2020 年，他留在特拉华州一家维修店且从未取回的笔记本电脑的内容被送到了共和党人手中，并被公开泄露，泄露了有关他工作和生活的个人信息。

尽管如此，亨特·拜登吸毒成瘾的照片仍经常在网上流传。拜登在他的回忆录中说，他可以对他们不屑一顾，因为他在家人的支持下走出了困境。

他在 2021 年的回忆录《美丽的事物》中写道：“我来自一个充满悲剧的家庭，被一种非凡、牢不可破的爱所束缚。”

在许多方面，拜登总统的政治生涯也可以这样说，1972 年他的妻子和女儿去世，就在拜登 30 岁宣誓就职参议院的前几天，他的政治生涯几乎中断了。

当时刚满 4 岁和 3 岁的儿子博和亨特受了重伤。两兄弟在医院一起度过了几个月，亨特写下的纽带牢不可破。他写道，即使他们晚年吵架，他们也总是以一句“我爱你”结束。

博是一位追求公共生活的人，他是一位获得勋章的伊拉克战争老兵和特拉华州司法部长。总统多次表示，应该是博作为总统而不是他自己上台。

亨特说他很满足于成为聚光灯下的博。但是当他的兄弟去世时，亨特失去了联系。他写道，有一次，他住在一家完全远离家人的汽车旅馆里，沉浸在吸毒的阴霾中。

“爸爸救了我，”他写道。 “如果我一个人离开，我肯定我活不下来。”

Now the hunger is being traced to corruption.

Preliminary findings released this month by Tigray regional authorities said they have tracked the theft of more than 7,000 metric tons of donated wheat — or 15 million pounds — in their region, taken by federal and regional authorities and others. The findings did not specify the time period. Other regions have yet to report amounts.

Ethiopia's government dismisses as harmful “propaganda” the suggestion that it bears primary responsibility for the disappearance of aid in Tigray and other regions, but it has agreed to a joint investigation with the US while the UN's World Food Program carries out a separate probe.

The way that Western aid officials “distance themselves from the accusations by linking the alleged problem only to government institutions and procedures is absolutely unacceptable and very contrary to the reality on the ground,” government spokesman Legesse Tulu told reporters earlier this month. He and other government spokespeople did not immediately respond to messages from the AP.

Aid workers say humanitarian agencies have long tolerated a degree of corruption by government officials. Provision of aid in Ethiopia has been heavily politicized for decades, including during the devastating famine of the 1980s, when the then-communist regime blocked assistance to areas controlled by rebel groups.

The senior USAID official told the AP that the latest theft of US and UN food aid included the manipulation of beneficiary lists that the Ethiopian government has insisted on controlling, looting by Ethiopian government and Tigray forces and forces from neighboring Eritrea, and the diversion of massive amounts of donated wheat to commercial flour mills in at least 63 sites.

A former Tigray official said government workers often inflate beneficiary numbers and take the extra grain for themselves, a practice that two officials with international organizations working in Ethiopia called widespread elsewhere in the country.

Numerous officials accused WFP of simply dropping off rations in the middle of towns, where much of the aid was looted by forces from Eritrea.

There were also signs that people whom the USAID official described only as “market actors” were forcing hungry families to surrender food aid they received — something that WFP suspects as well.

In Ethiopia, which has a history of deadly hunger, “zero” of the 6 million people in Tigray received food aid in May after the pause in donations by the US and UN, according to a UN memo seen by the AP. That's unprecedented, it said.

With 20 million people across Ethiopia dependent on such aid, plus more than 800,000 refugees from Somalia and elsewhere, independent humanitarian groups warn that even a quick resolution to the dispute could see many people starve to death.

In the UN food agency's first extensive public comments, the WFP regional director for East Africa, Michael Dunford, acknowledged possible “shortcomings” in its monitoring of aid distribution.

“We accept that we could have done better," he told the AP this week. But until now, Dunford said, “it's been very much the Ethiopian government that was managing” the process.

For USAID's part, the senior agency official cited a range of reasons that US officials missed the extent of the aid theft for so long. The war blocked the agency's ground access to the Tigray region for 20 months. Elsewhere in the country, COVID restrictions and security concerns limited USAID's oversight, the official said.

Some Republican and Democratic lawmakers said the rare countrywide suspension of aid showed USAID is taking the theft of US aid with appropriate seriousness. Asked if he was concerned about USAID oversight, a senior Democrat, Sen. Chris Coons of Delaware, said, “I'm concerned about the ways in which the Ethiopian military and government may have systematically diverted food that was meant for hungry Ethiopians.”

Sen. Jim Risch of Idaho, the top Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said “tough questions...need to be answered, and our partner must demonstrate some willingness to cooperate.”

“There must be a fundamental change in how we do food assistance in Ethiopia if we are going to resume USAID food aid there," Risch said, and called for accountability and transparency. "The first principle of humanitarian aid is to do no harm. From what I understand, harm has been done. We have to ensure for the American taxpayer that this doesn't continue to happen.”

US and UN officials said they were working to limit — or end — Ethiopian government officials' role in the aid system.

“We're taking back all the control over the commodities,” Dunford said. "The entire supply chain, from the time that we receive the food in the country to the time it's in the hands of the beneficiaries.” Plans include third-party distribution, real-time third-party monitoring and biometric registration of beneficiaries, he said.

The US government wants Ethiopia's government to remove itself from the compilation of beneficiary lists and the transport, warehousing and distribution of aid, according to a briefing memo by donors seen by the AP.

The senior USAID official said Ethiopia's government has committed to cooperate on reforms, but “we have not yet seen the specific reforms in place that would allow us to resume aid.”

Civilians, again, are suffering.

Ethiopia's harvest season is over and the lean season is approaching. The UN humanitarian agency has privately expressed fears of “mass starvation” in remote parts of Tigray, according to an assessment made in April and seen by the AP. Another assessment in May cited reports of 20 people dying of starvation in Samre, a short drive from the Tigray capital, Mekele.

Tigray's main hospital reported a 28% increase in the number of children admitted for malnutrition from March to April. At the hospital in Axum town, the increase was 96%.

“It is a good day if we manage to eat one meal,” said Berhane Haile, another of the thousands of war-displaced people going hungry.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Math and reading scores among America's 13-year-olds fell to their lowest levels in decades, with math scores plunging by the largest margin ever recorded, according to the results of a federal test known as the nation's report card.

The results, released Wednesday, are the latest measure of the deep learning setbacks incurred during the pandemic. While earlier testing revealed the magnitude of America's learning loss , the latest test casts light on the persistence of those setbacks, dimming hopes of swift academic recovery.

More than two years after most students returned to in-person class, there are still “worrisome signs about student achievement,” said Peggy G. Carr, commissioner of the National Center for Education Statistics, a branch of the federal Education Department.

“The 'green shoots' of academic recovery that we had hoped to see have not materialized,” Carr said in a statement.

In the national sample of 13-year-old students, average math scores fell by 9 points between 2020 and 2023. Reading scores fell by 4 points. The test, formally called the National Assessment of Educational Progress, was administered from October to December last year to 8,700 students in each subject.

Similar setbacks were reported last year when NAEP released broader results showing the pandemic's impact on America's fourth- and eighth-grade students.

Math and reading scores had been sliding before the pandemic, but the latest results show a precipitous drop that erases earlier gains in the years leading up to 2012. Scores on the math exam, which has been given since 1973, are now at their lowest levels since 1990. Reading scores are their lowest since 2004.

Especially alarming to officials were outsize decreases among the lowest-performing students. Students at all achievement levels saw decreases, but while stronger students saw slides of 6 to 8 points, lower performing students saw decreases of 12 to 14 points, the results show.

There were also differences by race. Students from almost every race and ethnicity saw math scores slide, but the steepest drops were among American Indian students, at 20 points, and Black students, at 13 points. The decline for white students, by comparison, was 6 points, while Asian students held even.

The scores reflect the disproportionate impact of the pandemic's disruptions on Black and Latino students and those from low-income families, said Denise Forte, president and CEO of the Education Trust, a nonprofit advocacy group.

“Students want to succeed, attend college, start a rewarding career and reach their full academic potential," Forte said. “But they can't if they continue to lose precious ground.”

Pandemic setbacks appear to be lingering even as schools across the US spend billions of dollars to help students catch up. The federal government sent historic sums of money to schools in 2021, allowing many to expand tutoring , summer classes and other recovery efforts.

But the nation's 13-year-olds, who were 10 when the pandemic started, are still struggling, Carr said.

“The strongest advice I have is that we need to keep at it,” she said. “It is a long road ahead of us.”

Education Secretary Miguel Cardona said the results confirm what the Biden administration knew all along: “that the pandemic would have a devastating impact on students' learning across the country and that it would take years of effort and investment to reverse the damage as well as address the 11-year decline that preceded it.”

Still, Cardona said he's encouraged by signs of improvement elsewhere, with some states returning to pre-pandemic levels on their own math and reading assessments.

The exam is designed to measure basic skills in math and reading. Students were asked to read passages and identify the main idea or locate certain information. In math, they were asked to perform simple multiplication and tackle basic geometry, calculating, for example, the area of a square. Most questions were multiple choice.

Asked about their reading habits, fewer students than ever say they're reading for fun every day. Just 14% reported daily reading for pleasure — which has been tied to better social and academic outcomes — down from 27% in 2012. Almost a third of students said they never or hardly ever read for fun, up from 22% in 2012.

The test also revealed a troubling increase in student absenteeism . The share of students missing five or more days of schools in a month doubled since 2020, reaching 10% this year. Students with fewer missed days had higher average scores in both reading and math, according to the results.

GRANTS PASS, Ore. (AP) — One Thursday morning in May, instead of sitting at a desk in her sixth grade classroom in the Oregon mountains, Khloe Warne sat at a table in her mother's bakery, doing her schoolwork on a laptop and watching her favorite clips of anime.

Khloe, 12, loves drawing, writing and especially reading — in second grade, she was already reading at a sixth grade level. But she only goes to school one day a week for two hours. The district said she needed shorter school days last year when Khloe threw a desk and fought with students in outbursts her mother attributes to a failure to support her needs. Khloe, who has been diagnosed with autism, ADHD and an anxiety disorder, had no individualized education plan for her disability when she returned to in-person learning after the pandemic.

Not being able to attend school regularly has saddened Khloe, stunted her education and isolated her from her peers, her mother says. It has also upended her family's life. Her mother, Alyssa Warne, had to quit her job for a time in order to stay home with her. She described the fight to get her daughter back in the classroom as exhausting, stressful and sad.

“She just wants a friend,” Alyssa Warne said. “It's not asking much to send your kid to school for at least one whole day.”

Across the US, advocates say, schools are removing students with disabilities from the classroom , often in response to challenging behavior, by sending them home or cutting back on the days they're allowed to attend.

Schools say the move can be necessary to keep students and teachers safe and prevent disturbances. But parents and advocates argue the shortened days, often referred to as informal removals , amount to discrimination and violations of students' civil rights. Under federal law, it is illegal to bar a child from receiving the same education as their peers based on conditions stemming from their disability.

Alyssa Warne sued her daughter's school and school district this month, alleging disability discrimination. School officials did not respond to requests for comment on the lawsuit. In an earlier email, the school director said she couldn't comment on individual students because of privacy concerns.

In Oregon, a clash between parents and schools culminated this spring at the Statehouse. A bill to curb the use of shortened days, essentially giving parents veto power over such a decision, is pending in the House of Representatives after near-unanimous passage in the Senate. Pressure from school boards and superintendents has hurt the legislation's chances, its chief sponsor said.

Advocates say schools across the US are removing students with disabilities from classrooms, often in response to challenging behavior, by cutting the days they're allowed to attend. Parents and advocates argue the move amounts to discrimination. (June 21) (AP video: Manuel Valdes, Claire Rush)

“It shouldn't have been controversial because these kids have had this right for such a long time,” Democratic state Sen. Sara Gelser Blouin said of her bill. “I wish that we could serve these kids, respect these kids and lift these kids up and honor their rights without being ordered by a court to do so.”

Dan Stewart, managing attorney for education and employment at the National Disability Rights Network, said he wasn't aware of other states with laws limiting schools' use of shortened days as Oregon's bill would have. But a number of states have issued guidance through their departments of education informing schools that shortened days could potentially amount to discrimination under federal law.

Since the 1970s, federal law has guaranteed students with disabilities the right to a free and appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment. This means, as much as possible, they should be learning alongside their peers who don't have disabilities, with necessary accommodations. It's illegal for school districts to cite a lack of money or staff as a reason for not educating a child with disabilities.

But states don't always enforce the law, advocates say. Instead of hiring specialists, training teachers or providing tailored services, they say, some schools are shortening students' schedules as a way to manage difficult behavior.

Oregon is embroiled in a lawsuit over schools' use of shortened school days, filed by the nonprofit advocacy group Disability Rights Oregon in 2019. Experts appointed by the court to research the issue found about 1,000 Oregon students with disabilities — most of them in elementary school — are on shortened schedules.

WASHINGTON (AP) — With inflation in the United States still excessive, most Federal Reserve officials expect to raise interest rates further this year, Chair Jerome Powell told a House committee Wednesday.

“Inflation pressures continue to run high, and the process of getting inflation back down to 2% has a long way to go,” Powell said on the first of two days of semi-annual testimony on Capitol Hill.

Even so, the Fed last week kept interest rates unchanged after 10 straight hikes so it could take time to gauge how higher borrowing rates have affected the economy, Powell said.

The contrast between the Fed's stated concern over still-high inflation and its decision to skip a rate hike has heightened uncertainty about its next moves. The hazier messaging suggests that Powell is seeking to balance competing demands from those Fed officials who want to keep raising rates and others who feel the central bank has done enough.

Asked on Wednesday to clarify last week's messaging, Powell told the House Financial Services Committee that keeping rates level was consistent with the Fed's increasing focus: Slowing the pace of its hikes in order to avoid raising rates higher than needed to reduce inflation and risk causing a deep recession in the process.

“It may make sense to move rates higher but to do so at a more moderate pace,” Powell said, likening the Fed's rate hikes to a journey. “As you get closer to your destination, as you try to find that destination, you slow down even further."

Partisan differences over the Fed's policies emerged at the hearing, with Rep. Patrick McHenry, the North Carolina Republican who chairs the committee, saying the central bank “must remain committed to eliminating this stealth tax on American workers and families,” referring to inflation. "And I urge you to continue that resolve.”

Yet Rep. Maxine Waters of California, the senior Democrat on the panel, said “the Fed made the right decision to pause interest rate hikes.”

In his remarks Wednesday, Powell also indicated that the Fed chose to keep its key interest rate steady last week so it could assess the impact of three large bank failures this spring on the banking sector and whether the failures would reduce credit to consumers and businesses and slow the economy.

Despite the Fed's focus on combating inflation, Republican committee members spent more time Wednesday questioning Powell about the central bank's stance on bank regulation. McHenry suggested that Congress consider removing the Fed's authority to regulate banks, if the policymakers take too strict an approach to overseeing small and medium-size lenders and potentially weaken lending.

After this year's bank failures, Michael Barr, the Fed's top financial regulator, indicated that the central bank might consider raising the level of capital that banks are required to hold in reserve against potential losses as a way to limit further failures.

But some committee Republicans argued Wednesday that requiring banks to hold more funds in reserve would restrict their ability to lend. Small businesses, they warned, would be especially hurt because they depend more on bank loans than do large companies, which can issue their own bonds. Reduced lending, they asserted, would weaken the economy.

Powell responded that any new such rules would likely focus on the largest US banks — those with more than $100 billion in assets, like Silicon Valley Bank and the other two institutions that failed. Community banks, by contrast, typically have under $10 billion in assets.

The Fed chair also said it could be several years before such rules would take effect. At the same time, he underscored that there is always a trade-off between requiring banks to hold certain levels of funds in reserve and encouraging lending. The challenge, he said, is to strike the right balance.

With inflation still well above the Fed's 2% target, most economists have said they believe that a rate hike at its next meeting in late July is all but assured. What actions the central bank might take after that remains much less clear. The policymakers indicated last week that they expect to raise rates twice more this year. Yet they might not follow through if economic data suggests that inflation is falling quickly back to their target level.

Speaking at a news conference last week, Powell said there were no plans to raise rates at every other meeting or to follow any other particular time frame. Instead, as he reiterated Wednesday, Fed officials will monitor economic data and make their rate decisions “meeting by meeting.”

The central bank's streak of rate increases have made borrowing for consumers and businesses more expensive across a range of loans, including home and auto loans, credit cards and business borrowing. The goal has been to cool inflation by slowing spending and hiring.

Last year, the Fed jacked up its benchmark rate at a breakneck pace, including by three-quarters of a point on four occasions. Now, with year-over-year inflation having eased from 9.1% a year ago to 4% , Powell has indicated that the Fed wants to move much more slowly.

A slower pace of rate increases, Powell has said, could help the Fed achieve a tricky feat: Weaken the economy enough to tame inflation, without undermining it so much as to cause a deep recession.

Yet on Wednesday, Powell repeated a warning he has often made: Defeating inflation won't be painless.

“Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below-trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions,” he said.

“Softer labor market conditions” would include rising layoffs and a higher unemployment rate. Fed officials, though, have said they hope to curb inflation mainly by reducing the number of open jobs rather than through mass layoffs.

Cutting demand for workers would allow employers to slow their wage increases, thereby helping keep a lid on inflation.

Last week, 12 of the 18 Fed's policymakers indicated that they envision at least two more rate hikes this year, and four predicted one additional increase. Only two officials forecast that the central bank will keep its key rate at its current level of 5.1% through year's end.

Stonehenge welcomes 8,000 visitors for the summer solstice

STONEHENGE, England (AP) — All hail the rising sun.

Around 8,000 revelers gathered around a prehistoric stone circle on a plain in southern England to express their devotion to the sun, or to have some communal fun.

Druids, pagans, hippies, local residents and tourists, many clad in an array of colorful costumes and even antlers, stayed and celebrated at Stonehenge for the night and greeted sunrise on Wednesday, which is the longest day in the Northern Hemisphere.

At dawn, the sun rose behind what is known as the Heel Stone in the northeast part of the horizon and the first rays shone into the heart of Stonehenge, one of the world's most famous prehistoric monuments and a World Heritage Site.

A sun-filled dawn followed a slightly misty sunrise, which was greeted with drumming, chanting and cheering.

“Stonehenge continues to captivate and to bring people together to celebrate the seasons, just as it has done for thousands of years,” said Nichola Tasker, director of Stonehenge at English Heritage, a charity that manages hundreds of historic sites.

“There was a wonderful atmosphere from sunset to sunrise, and everybody enjoyed a very atmospheric morning," she added.

Local police said two people were arrested on suspicion of a public order offense after they were refused entry due to intoxication.

“Everyone has been joyous, enjoying the event and having a glorious time and it has been peaceful and safe," said Wiltshire Police Chief Constable Catherine Roper, who attended the solstice for the first time.

In addition to the 8,000 people present, English Heritage said that approximately 154,000 people tuned in from around the world to watch the sunset and sunrise on the charity's livestream.

All over the UK, optimism will reign supreme as summer officially starts. It's no coincidence that the nearby Glastonbury Festival , one of the world's biggest music events, opens its doors on Wednesday, too. Both Stonehenge and Glastonbury supposedly lie on ley lines — mystical energy connections across the UK

For the thousands making the pilgrimage to Stonehenge, approximately 80 miles (128 kilometers) southwest of London, it is more than looking forward to Elton John at Glastonbury or a few ciders in the sun. Many of those present at Stonehenge will be making the short 50-mile (80-kilometer) journey further west to Glastonbury over the coming days.

For druids, modern-day spiritualists linked to the ancient Celtic religious order, Stonehenge has a centuries-long importance, and they performed their rituals around the solstice in their traditional white robes. It's effectively all about the cycle of life, of death and rebirth.

This year, the summer solstice at Stonehenge started at 7 pm Tuesday and ran through 8 am Wednesday. For this one night, worshippers are allowed to spend time inside the stone circle. Some chanted or played their acoustic guitars or banged their drums. Alcohol was prohibited, as were sound systems. Blankets were allowed, but no sleeping bags, please. And definitely, no climbing on the stones.

The rules have been tightened over the decades, certainly during the coronavirus pandemic. Back in the less-restrained past, tens of thousands would travel by foot, car, bus or motorcycle to worship at the solar temple, or just have a bit of fun.

Stonehenge is a symbol of British culture and history and remains one of the country's biggest tourist draws, despite the seemingly permanent traffic jams on the nearby A303 highway , a popular route for motorists traveling to and from the southwest of England.

Stonehenge was built on the flat lands of Salisbury Plain in stages starting 5,000 years ago, with the unique stone circle erected in the late Neolithic period about 2,500 BC Some of the stones, the so-called bluestones, are known to have come from the Preseli Hills in southwest Wales, nearly 150 miles (240 kilometers) away, but the origins of others remain a mystery.

The site's meaning has been the subject of vigorous debate, with some theories seemingly more outlandish, if not alien, than others.

English Heritage notes several explanations — from Stonehenge being a coronation place for Danish kings, a druid temple, a cult center for healing, or an astronomical computer for predicting eclipses and solar events.

The charity said the most generally accepted interpretation "is that of a prehistoric temple aligned with the movements of the sun.”

After all, the stones match perfectly with the sun at both the summer and winter solstices.

美国地区法官杰伊·穆迪 (Jay Moody) 发布了一项针对阿肯色州法律的永久禁令，该法律禁止医生向 18 岁以下的任何人提供性别肯定激素治疗、青春期阻滞剂或手术。

穆迪在 2021 年暂时阻止的阿肯色州法律也禁止医生将患者转诊到其他地方接受此类护理。至少有 19 个其他州已经根据阿肯色州的法律制定了限制或禁止对未成年人进行性别确认的护理的法律，并且几乎所有州都在法庭上受到质疑。

穆迪在他的命令中裁定，该禁令违反了跨性别青年和家庭的正当程序和平等保护权利。他说，该法律还侵犯了医疗提供者的第一修正案权利。
